posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Almost one week with the RG351v (ARKos). Thoughts so far:

- Battery reading is pretty inaccurate. Sometimes you turn it off, turn it on and the next time the percentage is a 1% higher

- Battery + built in wifi = bad: If you are going to download thumbnails / boxart or update cores / assets, do it while connected to the DC and disable wifi immediately after. It sucked a 30% just doing that.

- Gaming experience: Surprised to see it can do CPS3 with not a lot of hiccups. GBA paired with the LCD3X shader mitigates well enough the scaling artifacts when not using integer scaling. 240p PSX games like Klonoa are the ones that benefit the most from the small screen. Snes and Nes are as annoying as ever with the non square pixels if you have bad OCPD about stretching artifacts, as usual.

- Comfort: The d-pad is placed higher than on the og gameboy, so the corner gets into the soft of the hand and hurts a bit until you learn to adapt the posture. The analog stick placement justifies why I did not want the model with two of them. For Ridge Racer Type 4 I just place the left hand lower to not feel it too much. If I really wanted to play an analog only game, I would end using the Gamesir X2 instead.

- Commuting and travelling: Beats lugging around a Nintendo Switch for a quickie in the train. Easier to store. Loses points for not having bluetooth. I can do without wifi, but headphone cables are always a risk

- Did I really need this: Sure, it's cool to be able to play MVS Meta Slug X on the go, but then I ask myself why would I want to play on a "tiny screen" when I can do it on a 40" tv and see all the details. It's great as a replacement for aging handheld consoles, but for TV out consoles it may be better to get one of the other handhelds with bigger screens

That's it for now, I guess. Decent hardware, Need to find a pouch for it. the grey color, rather than the old GB, reminds me more of the Watara Supervisision.

i forget what the actual coined "law" for it, but it's basically: the time needed to complete a software project will fill up whatever time that is alloted for it. that is: if you're given a team and a year to finish a game, you'll finish it in that year. if you're given 5 years, it will take you 5 years.

it's mostly a reflection on software management and how it's changed. yeah sure devs have more tools and shit, but that's because their management gave them those tools. stop shitting on the devs and get angry at the people managing them. why is this SS remake taking so long? well, it's because they're not beholden to a release date. it's the same deal with star citizen. just because you're a good developer doesn't mean you're a good project manager.

it all starts with the management, folks

posts.com:
The Force Engine Linux port with working Audio and MIDI playback thanks to mlauss!
https://github.com/mlauss/TheForceEngine/tree/test-audio-select

Clone branch and compile then start Fluidsynth with
> fluidsynth -a alsa -m alsa_seq -g 1.0 -s /usr/share/sounds/sf3/default-GM.sf3
(or similar)

Then run the compiled binary and go to Settings > Sound > MIDI Output Device and specify the MIDI Output Device.

Enjoy!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9540012
>>9540247
I think this map is okay but I have many nitpicks that I'll try to address roughly in order of appearance. I wish there were a few more bullets at the start since shooting the elevated skeletons at the start feels drawn out with the shotgun. I really dislike that some of the rock/sand piles around the start have impassible lines for no reason since it can block your dodging without any telegraph. This is especially annoying since not all of them are like this. Like the other post said already, many descended midtextures are visibly clipping through the floor with software rendering (you can fix this by varying the brightness value or flat between the surrounding sectors). The ambush before the rocket launcher is a blatant example of hitscanners without cover, the computer in the center isn't tall enough to protect you. I wish there were some consistency about which doors are intractable since inert/onesided doors look the same as normal ones. Using spectres as soon as you enter a dark room twice in the same map feels kind of lazy. Both archviles feel poorly used since the first one is trivial since he can never get behind you and the other is just a test of patience since it can never get down the lift. I didn't realize there was a lift at first since there's no indication it's intractable and it looks the same as the surrounding walls. I feel like the revenant/imp ambush by the computer switches would work a lot better if the wall above you were shorter so the enemies could shoot down at you when they get caught against the wall. I have no idea what the switch before the blue key lift is for since it seems like you can and should safely ignore it. The lost souls in the end room feel completely pointless since you can just kill them before you hit the switch, I'd honestly just remove them since the fight's hard enough anyway. You can also softlock yourself if you ride the perpetual lifts in that room up and jump over the wall. Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541481
A lot of the interconnectedness in this level feels unmotivated since it'll often lead you places you have no reason to return to. The visuals in the map are unpolished, I don't know why you'd use a high quality texture pack like Otex if you aren't even going to align your textures (not just aligning your similar textures to each other but also aligning seams of the textures with the edges of geometry. Otex was designed from the ground up for this, I'm not sure why so many people don't bother). Using a combination of stock and Otex also tends to look incongruous, you can sometimes get away with it but it shouldn't really be necessary given the latter's comprehensiveness.
This probably comes off as a scathing review but I'd like to stress that none of these things ruin the map, and I liked many of the ideas present even if the execution was flawed. I especially liked the big imp ambush and the last room, minus the lost souls. If you're interested in contributing to community projects I'd say you're already more capable than a lot of participants.

>>9533387
It does but it's a huge pain. The only way I can get DualShock rumble to work the way it does on console is to add Duckstation to Steam so it sees it as an Xinput controller, then change the vibration bias to like 138 in the controller options to actually get it to vibrate each motor correctly. Otherwise Playstation controllers overall don't rumble right when wrapped as Xinput (even the DS4 it turns out, although Duckstation supports that natively) and support for vibration as a Dinput controller is non-existent. I think you can accomplish this in PCSX2 as well (and I think that has some DS3 mode which might work for that controller, or is that RPCS3?) by changing the vibration percentages above 100% but I don't actually use PCSX2 so I'm not going to fiddle with it.

There's an Xbox One converter and I have no idea if it handles it any better and accounts for the different vibration standards or just does the same shit as the software input wrappers.

AoW seems to be written in Delphi, judging from the .dpl files (they're just dlls btw).
The UI uses the Visual Component Library that is based on Win32 API but adds a lot of custom controls. Looks like it was one of the easiest way to build good looking GUIs in Windows at the time.

As for VNs from that time, maybe they used the Windows API with custom engines in C or C++ or even languages like Hot Soup Processor.
Then engines like KiriKiri and Nscripter got popular.

>>9537293
the key difference from back then and now is that there was a clear divide between cutscene and gameplay, not this blending of the two where the game is constantly taking control away from the player to make it 'seamless', or forcing you to do slow walking sections, or """hidden loading""" screens by walking through small cracks in a wall. all these severely hamper future playthroughs thanks to all the stops.

in mgs1/2/3 you can just skip the cutscene and codec, and very rarely does the game stop you to show you the end goal mid gameplay, things like "a surveillance camera" cutscene in 1, or the "RAVEN!?" cutscene in 2 can be skipped right away. The game doesn't hand hold you constantly unless you call the codec and then they'll give you advice.
The gameplay also didn't take a hit because of it's story, like most cinematic games do now. There's a lot of replayability and experimentation in these games, specially 2 and 3 with all the fun tools it gives you to mess with the guards, most cinematics games are basic, and not there's not a lot of room for experimentation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Magazines and the average pleb saw it as the most amazing things and video games "maturing".

The thing is, people were even more insecure about the media back then. So when people were able to say "Look! It's like a movie!", for them it's a way to "prove" their media isn't childish toys for pre schoolers, it's also "just like that stuff you watch on TV all the time!"

Little did/do they people realize that "being like movies" is exactly what brings the media down. By imitating movies, video games are always a step behind. Some books or movies are able to create new trends, trends that others will copy and even transcend the media to reach other media. No video game has ever created such a trend exactly because they are too busy being this cool cinematic stuff that re-enacts the current trends.
Instead, video games could have been so much more, create their own story telling techniques that no other media could have, and yet we've barely scratched the surface of that potential. Because everyone is too busy trying to appear just like that cool movie people like so they can hand prices to each others like it was the Oscars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9538827
3 has the worst gameplay and is imo the worst main MGS in general. A lot of systems that are convoluted seemingly for their own sake: the cure system with the RNG wounds that literally just waste your time healing (it's not even another difficulty layer since you just pause the game and nothing can happen to you), the camo menu, the awful CQC, the weight limits. The way MGS2 handles wounds is more effective (even though it's like something out of a cartoon) because it plays out in real time instead of a menu, healing supplies are scarce on higher difficulty levels, and the tighter maps combined with the faster guards means that leaving a trail of blood is actually a serious problem, besides being much better and more streamlined gameplay anyway, while you get stuck on trees and other shit in MGS3 all the time because the gameplay formula is designed around blocky, sterile rooms and not messy jungles. Not even sure why they fucked with the radar just because it would be "more realistic", as if a health bar would be realistic, but the only result is that you spend a lot more time waiting and looking at primitive 3D graphics.

The MGS2 alert system is completely unpolished in this game, which becomes especially apparent in the weapons lab, where it's always more time-efficient to just let soldiers kill you or reload your game instead of waiting for the alert and guards to fuck off, similar to the bad gameplay in games like The Evil Within, where you can run into traps and lose 99% your health right after a checkpoint. In older games, you could usually do something or the checkpoints were less forgiving.

The bosses feel even more like cinematic experiences than in previous games, one even letting you win by literally just waiting. Both friends and foes are uninteresting in comparison with 1 and especially 2, radio conversations just being .jpgs now and a generic super soldier with anime powers the main villain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9537293

At first more "cinematic" meant that the entire gaming industry is expanding what CAN be done within the medium and there was much hype for it.
The jump to CDs and later DVDs also allowed far more high production level content to be packed in and that opened up the potential.

But starting with MGS2 I think the line between "too much" was well defined. MGS2 in particular had a demo that everyone played into oblivion and when the actual game got released later and you got essentially a visual novel with a bit of gunplay people soured on it.
I think that was a moment where it became clear that too much of it meant there's not enough "game" in your game.
That's why MGS3 in particular tones it down and gives you far more gameplay to work with.

Later on (today's gaming era) the entire field got saturated by movie-producing wannabes that see the medium as a platform for their b-movie sensibilities and "storytelling" and it's again choking the medium. Luckily this time around you have a million indie games if you don't want AAA movie-games.

>>9516704
You can clean mold off VHS tapes. Open top case of VCR. Fast forward the tape. As its running, lightly press Qtip dipped in rubbing alcohol against the capstan so the tape runs across it. Cleans all the mold off. I've done it several times and saved some rare tapes this way.

rgb's only necessary if you think it is. composite's ok if you're ok with it. rgb makes the video signal cleaner so you don't get certain video artifacts that you do with composite. some people actually prefer composite because of those artifacts. the only time rgb might be "necessary" is if the console or whatever only outputs rgb (i can't think of any examples of this, maybe there's a computer like this) or if there's some detail you can't make out on composite, which might be discernible on rgb but it could just be that the screen itself can't resolve the detail (because of dot pitch or convergence or what have you).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536724
To properly diagnose this, open the TV up and get a blowdrier. Heat up the big capacitors near the power board until they're about as warm as lukewatm water. If you switch the tv on and it turns on instantly it's definitely bad caps. Any bulging caps are certainly bad. Replace those with caps of the same voltage and capacity (seen as uf or mf commonly.) This isn't a critical problem, but it will slowly add wear and tear to the circuitry if you don't replace caps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's what I don't understand about this thread. So help me out here.

Do you people push CRTs because you think they are superior to LCDs, and refuse to change?

Or

Do you people push CRTs because you have old equipment that simply isn't compatible with new LCDs TVs (like an old NES or SNES) without an adapter?

I work for a fairly busy independently owned arcade/family fun bar and we have a mix of CRT arcade games and newer LCD arcade games.

We do repairs on the older arcade CRT games, but parts are getting harder to acquire. I would like to preserve the original design of these machines as they were made from the arcade factory. I want people to experience what it was like when these machines came out in the 80s and 90s.

However....for some broken machines we can't find the original arcade monitors anymore. Or some of the machines just can't quite stand up to the heavy usage they once did back in the 90s and constantly go down for maintenance. Usually the issues revolve around the CRT monitors.

We are thinking about adapting old CRT TVs as replacement arcade monitors. But based on what we're reading some people expressed that this isn't the way to go. That it's a janky way of doing it, and not reliable.

A new debate has started between the the arcade techs, owners, etc. Basically if we are going to all this trouble of Trying to adapt CRT TVs for arcade use, then maybe we should just use replacement LCD panels instead and maybe find a way to use a scanline filter to try to get close to the CRT look.

The argument is that "Its better to have people play these games even with an LCD compared to constantly having games go down due to CRT issues. Thar LCDs would solve 90% of the problems."

Others have said it's better to preserve the original condition from the factory or try to. Use CRTs.

I can see both arguments. What are your thoughts? We are not located in the United States. So replacement parts for us is hard to get and shipping costs can get costly

>>9532438
Anyone ever notice that Cut Man and Wood Man were always part of the same shot in the opening animation? It's Wood Man, Centaur Man, Spark Man, Skull Man, Gyro Man, Cut Man, and Freeze Man. These are different from the RobotMasters shown in earlier in the FMV since those were dramatized flashbacks of the original games - this is a new scene of robots from each game ganging up on Mega Man. So my theory is that Cut Man and Wood Man from the Saturn version are a remnant of a much bigger plan for the PlayStation version. I really think you were originally supposed to revisit each level ala Mega Man 3, which is why a lot of Bolts require a second visit. Recall that Mega Man 8 was supposed to be the 10-anniversary game. There was probably a plan to make that series celebration more evident, but things fell through.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9534810
>Honestly think this problem's overstated, but then again I never compared them back to back. I can imagine scrolling with that effect might be a problem on a crappy TV.
It's an issue in exactly one part of the game: the spike-section in the first half of Aqua Man's stage. The reason is because there's a series of spike floors and ceilings that you have to carefully navigate through. In PlayStation version, this section is easier to navigate since the visibility is perfectly clear. In Saturn version, because the long spikes are affected by the new water effect, it's inadvertently harder to determine the spike tips and platform edges, making it easier to instantly lose a life. I can attest to game-overing here on Saturn while it was a breeze on PlayStation. There are more spikes in an optional area in the second half of the level, but they're shorter, the tunnel is a lot less narrow, and there's much less going on visually, so it shouldn't be a problem there. You might be able to fix the issue by if you were to keep the water wave effect only in the background (The Wily Wars does a similar thing in Bubble Man's stage) or you leave it out of there like most Mega Man games.

I'm not sure if you're being sarcastic, but it truly did. These camera based games that work off of the player's body movement paved the way for VR. Without the eyetoy and whatever the gameboy camera was, we wouldn't have had the Wii.

The Wii was gimmicky, but in 2010, this guy used the wii sensor bar, put it on his head and flipped it around to make this tech demo. I remember my jaw hitting the floor when I first saw it. That's when I knew that true VR games were going to be a reality. Today, I'm a simdad with a VR cockpit and games like iRacing and Il-2 are amazing. As the tech becomes cheaper and more readily available to the average consumer, VR gaming is going to explode.

Its two fundamentally different playstyles. JSR is closer to older skating games where skating was something you had to learn to control. Where as THPS just makes it easier to control since its meant to make you feel like an expert off the bat.
>>9529553
It is, but I found it really cozy in a way. Reminds me of urban exploration and finding big, empty areas that are long abandoned and dilapidated. The emptier JSRF spots are basically an elaborated versions of the outskirts of the JSR maps
Ultimately, JSR is a game taking place where the environment isn't built for skating; the skill comes in maximizing how well you can skate in environments actively working against you.
JSRF is a world built like a giant skate park. Both have their merits.

>>9539849
Agreed. I played future for the first time recently and while JSR was one of the most strangely frustrating games I've played in recent memory, I found myself missing how the original game handled while playing its sequel. The difficult controls give you a real sense of friction. It's like actually trying to learn something difficult. You fail over and over until you start to figure out the tricks and pretty soon you're cruising. It's a much more rewarding game. I also think the aesthetics just pop more. Future is oddly dreary. Tagging was downgraded too. The original tagging was an odd fit but I don't think making it mindless was the solution.

That said, the enemies in JSR can fuck off. That's my only real complaint. They aren't fun to deal with, they are purely nuisances and when you get hit it feels like bullshit most of the time. Especially with those flying fuckers near the end of the game.

>>9527356
>don't think I've ever seen a source for that but I've read it in other places. I don't know where the rumor comes from or if it's true.
Right, but it's definitely an idea that's been going around online, true or not. It's a small form of vindication for me at any rate, even finding out that it's definitely untrue would be interesting enough for me.

With some extensive Googling and searching, I found a couple of references to it on TVTropes (unsourced, and who knows when they were added), a brief thread about it on R*ddit from earlier this year, and then some scant few mentions of it in the archives of /vr/ and /v/ dating back the past decade or so.
If it's actually true, potentially the one source is actually in Japanese and it's something that's only been wandering around the western world by word of mouth, and either it was never translated, or the translation of it fell off the web at some point.

What we have to back it is 1, that the claim of the idea has been passed around for a long time (never challenged and never sourced), but of slightly stronger substance, 2, there's some interviews with the devs where they do actually mention that Namco made them change a number of things about the game to tone it down, such as making the zombies less realistic and human looking, making the blood green, etc.
There's no mention about the concept of the player character, but that wouldn't have to mean that it wasn't something which changed during development, regardless of it was something changed in the last minute as often told of, or if it was something which was proposed but nixed early on. The player initially being proposed as an evil killer looking to murder a poor girl, then being changed into a hero trying to save his girl would be going from a darker to a lighter tone, and it would make the fact that the player looks like a famous slasher horror killer less inexplicable.

Maybe, but I'd argue that on top of all the gimmicks, it has pretty damn good fundamentals. Real good hits and feedback, solid enemy roster with just enough variety, combos feel good, and there's some moderate nuances to the system like being able to stagger combos.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536428
It isn't complex, no, but there's an appeal in that in itself, Doom is better than Wolfenstein 3D, because the latter is very plain in comparison, but there's a certain fun purity in it too which works (and there's actually a little bit more depth to Wolf3D than people give it credit for). Compare also to how Super Mario Bros. 3 is categorically better than the first Super Mario Bros. and has way more depth, with far more content of greater variety, but it's still fun to play the first one anyway.

If you look at Splatterhouse and think that it should have more complexity to it, then what you'd be looking at is Splatterhouse 3, which has a little bit more gameplay depth, and which also actually has multiple endings. The western release has those endings hanging on really a very strict time limit, so it's actually pretty hard to get the best ending, but the Japanese one is essentially the same (down to being in English), but with a far less harsh timer. Opinions are divisive in the fandom about a lot of things, but there's many who think the third Splatterhouse is the best one, while some dislike how it deviates from the simpler style of the previous games.

There's also the infamous reboot, which isn't really retro (I guess it's sort of a remake, but not really?). Tastes are divided on that one as well, but there's a lot of people who think that while it's indeed rather flawed, the game is actually pretty decent for what it is, and works well enough with the property.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536624
I love the atmosphere throughout, but Splatterhouse was always quite in your face with the gore, that was the point. I think that the gore is actually rather impressive for the hardware they were working with, mainly to get viscera that good and detailed on a TurboGfx-16 and Sega Genesis, with equally disgusting monster design.
From the arcade game in 1988, to Splatterhouse 3 in August 1993, I can't think of any remotely popular videogame available in the west which has this quality of gore and in these quantities. The only rival is Doom, which is fantastic (especially in that regard), but wouldn't be on the market until December of 1993, and was working with far more permissive memory and color palettes.

Actually, I suppose those Elvira games were quite gory, and about the horror, though they were some sort of adventure games, as opposed to Splatterhouse and Doom being realtime action games, so I guess I could attach that qualifier.

>>9536654
I think that there was no change in the content itself between the Japanese version and the two international versions. They differ slightly, but I think it's little code tweaks/fixes.
There was changes during development of all sorts of kinds (the devs mentioned that the blood used to be red before Namco had them changed to green, for instance), but that was before it made it onto the Japanese market itself. There's some leftover stuff in the release versions, but I'm not sure if it was left out for censorship reasons, as much as things which they cut because they thought didn't fit or was good enough, or because of hardware limitations or not having the time to refine it to the point that they liked.

I think the first one is just a bit hard to get into and not quite as...expansive? as some of its contemporaries.

On the former point, while memorization and trial and error are blatant in a lot of games of the time (though not as much as some people think IMO), some of the stuff in the game just feels annoying to lose a credit too (poltergeist room in particular comes to mind, Biggyman too if you don't know how to beat him with slides or the double shotgun cheese).

When I say expansive...what I mean is like, comparing the gameplay to say Castlevania 1 (odd comparison I know, but it's one of the only classics I can think of which has a similar level of commitment in its movement and attacks) and I feel like there's just a lot more going on in that game in terms of enemy patterns, platforming, secondary systems like sub weapons, etc. at least IMO

Not trying to shit on the game mind you. It's far from a kusoge or anything, it's very functional, plays smooth, and has some great segments and stages. But it's gameplay is a bit stiff and limited IMO. Maybe I'll revisit it today.

>Why is it so much better than the other sequels?
I guess it depends on one's personal taste. I like it because it was a nice change from the religious cult storyline though unfortunately SH2 indirectly killed the series with everyone and their mothers trying to replicate the story and the "muh trauma" part of it.
>Will you play the new remake?
No, Silent Hill 2 is Silent Hill 2. Everything else will be fanfiction for the zoomies who can't even play a game with fixed camera angles and tank controls. Useless.
>And what's the cannon ending?
Guy Cihi (the VA for James) considers the "In Water" ending to be canon. Someone from staff (I can't remember who) considers the Leave ending to be canon. If Silent Hill 3's Douglas went to Silent Hill to investigate about James (the missing person's case he talks about in the car with Heather), then In Water might be canon OR James decided to just vanish and is still alive, hence Leave being canon.
>Also how and why did Laura come to Silent Hill?
Probably with the help of Eddie if the introduction video is to be believed. As to why, Mary told her about Silent Hill a lot and she thought the "beautiful place" in her letter referred to Silent Hill, not Heaven you go to after you die.

There is no canon ending, every ending beside the joke endings are presented as equally valid. In SH4 James' father, Frank, will comment that his son "disappeared in Silent Hill", leaving his fate ambiguous.
>>9540091
Not that anon but overall as an actual video game I would say that SH3 is the best as well. Unlike SH1 and SH2, which are too generous with resources, SH3 actually provides a nice challenge in how you manage your resources, you get more physical weapons in order to never truly softlock yourself but the hand gun has been nerfed hard from SH2 and ammunition for your other guns is rather scarce, especially on higher difficulty. Level design has been refined and you get a good balance of feeling like you've explored the whole area after completing each dungeon. Enemies are more designed around gameplay roles rather then strictly symbolism for the narrative, something not to everyone's liking, but it makes replays more interesting I feel. Other mechanics like stamina and the block also feel more refined and more consistently relevant in gameplay. On top of this I would say SH3 is in general the scariest as well, it has a lot of great moments like the mirror room and haunted house chase. SH3's real issue I would say lie in the narrative, which is honestly a bigger deal with a series like SH compared to other game series.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you're trying to learn Japanese by playing retro games, in my opinion there's nothing better than the EMIT trilogy by Koei.
Visual novels are ideal for learning Japanese in general, but EMIT was specifically made as language teaching software so it goes above and beyond. The whole VN is written in both English and Japanese and you can flip back and forth at any time, and it even includes an in-game dictionary.
The story is fun and the whole trilogy is only about 90 minutes long in total. You can read it on about any platform you can imagine.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9542513
Here's a literal rendering. It's really line 3 that gets gutted in the process, even if it's pretty well implied
>I've been calling from the train station.
>It started to rain, and I wanted (to tell) someone to bring me an umbrella.
>But the line's been tied up, and I couldn't get through at all.
However, taking the last line at its literal value sort of misses that he's admonishing his daughter who is holding the phone right there as he's walking in. As if to say
>But SOMEONE's been tying up the line, and I couldn't get through
So while it doesn't cling to the source text word-for-word, it does properly convey the intent. Too bad that's not really good for teaching people a language, who might be scratching their heads about why the conversation plays out so differently.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542232
Sonic (and other Sega games like Alex Kidd, Streets of Rage with 3, etc) had a tendency to have more plot than their contemporaries at the time. The Japanese Sonic manuals always had complex stories and while they're questionable in how well they gel (especially the original implication of each island having its own set of Chaos Emeralds), they nevertheless build on what came before. Then Sonic 3 started adding story elements to the actual game, which is more obvious if you play through it as 3&K where the attempted relaunch of the Death Egg happens midway through rather than as the climax of one game.
For Sonic Adventure (which I believe was supposed to be an RPG at that), they transferred that over to the actual game as well, which basically became their style for the 3D games.
Of course, how well it works depends on your suspension of disbelief.

Small hitboxes (which came quite a bit later) were the downfall of the genre because it meant stages changed from interesting level design, macro dodging, hazard dodging, interesting setpieces, learning routes and tactics, etc to now just static backgrounds, enemies with no thematic cohesion or relevance, and having these complex slow-moving curtains of bullets with tiny little hitboxes that you slowly weave through with your tiny little hitbox.

The hitboxes in Silver Surfer are great because it's literally exactly as it shows: your whole character, and you can easily tell where the stage hazards are by what you can't shoot through. The slow scroll and tight controls allow you to weave through the levels with ease.

>>9541762
Shaders are only half of the equation. The best ones already emulate scanlines and phosphor masks very well when used at very high resolutions. However, the display matters a lot as well, and it's where the bottleneck truly lies. You need at least 4K resolution, HDR with very high brightness and strobing to properly replicate things like scanline bloom and smooth motion while having a nice vibrant picture. In lieu of that, some shaders try to fake the bloom and glow of a CRT screen, but these aren't all that convincing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fundamentally different implementation of 3D
Rather than just taking a bunch of triangles that are twisted and turned to make a 3D shape they used something called NURBS. This approach comes from the CAD software that 3D modelling workstations were originally meant to run, and to this day is still used for high-accuracy CAD work.
However as real-time 3D accelerators are meant specifically for polygons those are used in games instead. You'll see a lot of NURBS models used in PS1-era FMVs as those were often made on SGI workstations that were optimized for this kind of workload.

>>9537436
This comment puts it in too simple terms, but basically gets it. The people who were producing basically any kind of visuals that are now considered the peak of "soulful" and "retro" graphics, were just extremely talented and disciplined people working within the limitations of older software/hardware. Retro fags like us who recognize the aesthetic appeal of that time are appreciating all these things in a completely different context. So when modern indie devs go for that look, they can usually recreate the technical limitations and specifics, but lack the top-of-the-line skill and the time-specific mindsets of those eras. An overblown example for comparison would be a modern archeologist trying to recreate ancient egyptian sculpture. He could get the tech down through research, but there's no way to recreate the mindset and education of those ancient artists.

>>9537435
The hell are you talking about? Sounds like you're confusing NURBS with a combination of subdivision modeling and path tracing. NURBS are mostly used for static models in industrial/design settings. All of the 90's/80's CGI videos (such as those posted by the OP) were done with graphics that used normal polygon meshes (usually subdivided), textured and prerendered with pathtracing. You cannot rig and animate an organic, strechable object like a horse or a humanoid with NURBS. You also cannot texture it with much freedom.

I feel like we'll get there by a small group of true blue autists, the kind that truly are mentally set apart to accomplish tasks otherwise infeasible, will make it their goal to either emulate or recreate that technology for the pure sake of preserving the ability to do so, and then a lesser group of passionate individuals will take that work and make games with it. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A major reason is because it's pretty ugly and limited. You basically can't create facial expressions unless you're intentionally going for a goofy look. Not on normal characters anyway. Even back in the day, memorable individual characters had to be pretty special to easily emote, like Hexadecimal from Reboot.

There's also the, ya know, over 20 years of traction that 2D pixel art has gained notoriety for since 3D "took its place". People have been making pixel art themselves for a long time and uploading it on the net. There's been a lot of time for people to recognize that your average SNES game looked better than your average PSX game because 3D came too soon. Your average indy developer is a product of this and focused a lot of their free time creative habits on 2D, not 3D.

Also, something else has to be brought up concerning what people have said about talent. The reality is that artists have way less say in how a video game turns out as compared to other people, especially if its a project where you're doing a lot of the development work yourself (using very little frameworks or middleware). The average artist has no idea how to get the weapon effects in Amid Evil to work like they do, and they didn't back in the day, either. The people working on the engine create those kinds of visual effects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
No self respecting artist wants to intentionally recreate something that looked like complete dog-ass.

Artists want to push boundaries and do the best they can with the available tools. That's what this art style was originally born of- It was the best they could do with the limitations of the time. They were learning as they worked, pioneering into something totally new.

Even if a modern artist wanted to work within the technical limitations of the time, for whatever reason, they still wouldn't recreate something that looks like 90s CG did. They would work differently, they would have access to greater resources, they'd have the accumulated knowledge of 20 years of progress, and they'd make something that looks better.

You are nostalgic for this stuff because it is evocative of a specific period you remembe fondly. But an artist will always strive to create the best they can with their tools. Nostalgia on it's own is a shit reason to make shitty art, so even if you crave that specific flavour of shitty art more than anything, it's likely to stay in it's time. Where it belongs. And where it should be respected.

4k is 2160 lines but many games render every second/third one and cheap upscale.
The thing people are talking about with nurbs etc is, parts of the model aren't specified by triangles they're specified by math like the tip of marios finger would be 'there's a sphere here with this radius, it stops half way and turns into a cylinder,...' then when you go to render it the image's pixel grid is laid over that and then it's simple math to say 'if I, a pixel, am here, and a sphere is centered there, then if i was a triangle on its surface i would be facing this way and since the light is there, i'm thus this color'. and mario's fingertip might get 5000 triangles but your model only specified like 10 numbers for it

See the green wireframe at the back in pic related (it's not a mesh of triangles - the lines curve)

The data needed wasn't much, but the generated output was into gigabytes, especially if you were doing movies. And it took hours and hours to do 1 frame. That's where the term rendering farm comes from, since you had fridge sized workstations with 64 CPUs and dozens of hdds inside processing every frame, networked together working in unison.

CGI in 90s movies took up to a year or more to render on several workstations like that.

>>9539724
>data went into
>gigabytes
I'm not sure what you're really asking when it comes to data in/out, I have never really heard things talked about in those terms. As i explained to you a pure shape doesn't need anywhere near as much data to store the model as would the same shape approximated by many triangles.
If you render a single sphere with one camera and one light (with scanline micropoly OR raytracing) your spatial 'data input' is basically
>sphere position with respect to camera x y z
>light position with respect to camera x y z
>sphere radius
>light direction
like 50 bytes or something, and you might get out a 150MB 8000x8000 .bmp file. If doing scanline, then in between, unseen by you but by the computer, yes a fuckload more memory would be used, but not at once, so you wouldn't need a gigabyte of memory to do it.
But maybe if you wanted to do your sphere real time today with the scanline algorithm, you do need gigabytes to store all the micropoly at once since you don't have time to load and unload the ones to do with different pixel blocks. Hence why UE5 is only just about able to do this today on the ps5 at 2000 lines

That, anon, is ray tracing, especially in the 90s.

> I think even with non-ray traced lighting the aesthetic would still be there, just not as bold.

I get your meaning, and it's true, but to be pedantic remember that ray-tracing literally IS the lighting. You set the light source(s), you set the objects, you set the camera location, and then the rendering engine emits light rays from the light source, off the objects and into the camera, at whatever resolution you've got the RAM and storage for

it's pretty wild the variety of scenes you can construct using the method of rendering, especially considering that the actual geometry files for something like this was probably about 20 kilobytes and the textures not much more.

>>9539732
My guy, are you sure? AFAIK, scanline rendering is one of the two options (the other being Z-buffering; they are also combinable) for determining what is visible in 3D scenes - that is: determining what objects are "in front" of other objects, thus rendering them fully, and everything thats "behind" them gets renderred partially.
It has nothing to do with lighting algorithms, which are a different algorithm that can be combined with those that determine visible surface.
Although AFAIK raytracing is an umbrella term and can be used both for visible surface determining and lighting algorithms. The current Nvidia RTX stuff is a hodge-podge of partial raytracing used mostly for reflections that is then upscaled and integrated with other more "classic" realtime techniques.
But I might be wrong about some of this, so someone please correct me...

Another reason that muh ray-tracing is the wrong direction to pursue when trying to reach the 90s look is that a very distinctive aspect of the renders is that light does NOT bounce, at all. If you don't have a light aimed on some part of the scene, it is BLACK.
Ray-tracing is all about bouncing rays of light and 'view' around the scene so that a bit of red from the red ball goes onto the white ground, etc. This bleed is the lighting feature that 'sells' reality to your unconscious* mind and the beauty of 90s rendering was that it DIDN'T have this 'so you knew you were in a dream'.

* i say unconscious because you don't see it until you look you just say yep that's real. look at pic related for example and now i point it out you can see a very obvious pink glow on the pillow under his face. normally you never would have seen it

This is literally the worst designed boss in existence on hard difficulty.

There is no rhyme or reason or tells to any of his movements. His swaying is completely fucking random, when he decides to go in is completely fucking random, and how many attacks he does when he goes in is also totally fucking random. Not to mention his fake-outs are indecipherable from his attacks until the very last second, which combined with the massive hitbox and the fact that he oftentimes sways above/below you right before going in, you oftentimes will physically not have enough time to react, as you have to scale literally half the wall in a fraction of a second.

As someone who has played and mastered a lot of games, I could instantly tell within about a minute or two (after determining that there is no memo and it's all pure RNG bullshit) that this was a poorly designed shit boss from an incompetent hack; and usually Konami are pretty good, so I am very disappointed. Of course, I decide to check a no-miss hard run just to see how players tackled it. Of course, just as I thought and confirming my suspicions, literally the only way anyone ever deals with it is to use a bomb combined with the C-C weapon swap spam exploit. There is zero consistent method that doesn't involve the weapon swap spam exploit, and even that is likely not consistent every run due to the extreme RNG. Again, if he decides to sway towards your escape direction right before going in, you are FUCKED; there is no literally physical way you can escape in time, as even jumping literally does not give you enough time to escape.

Went through literally the exact same thing with my ex wife. I assumed, incorrectly, that she would stop pressuring me to get rid of my stuff after we moved out of our cramped apartment and into a house and had a bit more space. If anything, the pressure intensified, even though we had a 2,300 sqft house with absolutely fuck all in it. Divorce was painful but worth it in the end. My current house is a little over half the size of the one we had together, but I actually have control over it, and don't just live in it like some kind of pet while my wife makes all the decisions and lords over me. My current gf is also way more laid back, way less controlling, and just a generally all around better person than my ex.

>>9531119
When my friend had his first kid, I told him "congratulations", and he responded "thanks buddy... guess I'll see you in 10 years". Since his kid was born 3 years ago, I can count the number of times I've seen him on one hand. What's really sad is that it's unlikely to get better. I wasted a total of 4 years with my ex wife, then I had to recover from the divorce, then get out dating again. Even if my gf and I got married and had a kid by this time next year (unlikely), there would still be a significant age gap (5+ years) between my kid and most of my friends' kids. A lot of parents, most of my friends included, keep in touch by organizing "play dates" with kids of similar age, but my kids wouldn't really be able to play with the others because they would be at different development stages. So I feel increasingly shut-out of this once-close circle of friends. Feels bad man.

>>9533447
That article is blatantly wrong. The program was not made as a diss, and it was definitely not shown to any lawyers as an act of pettiness, it was just a silly private joke shown to a couple friends.

Here's David Crane's personal explanation of it:
>“The Venetian Blind cart is a working 2600 demo that shows a landscape at sunset outside a window, covered by a fully operational Venetian Blind — one that moves up and down under joystick control. Here is how it came about:
>When Atari sued Activision they laid claim to certain ‘proprietary’ techniques. One technique for which they claimed ownership was first used by Bob Whitehead in the display code of the Atari Chess cartridge. This method moved the display objects back and forth every scan line to allow the game to display more objects. On the chess pieces, for example, Bob showed the odd pixel row of the odd numbered columns of pieces and the even pixel row of the even numbered columns. We called this the Venetian Blind technique since it made the pieces look like they were being viewed through a venetian blind.
>One day in the lab at Activision while the lawsuit was in full swing, Bob and I collaborated on a practical joke. We made a display showing an architecturally accurate window with a view of a grassy hill at sunset. We covered it with a venetian blind effect that animated up and down (complete with the stacking up of the slats as they were gathered up by the blind mechanism). We took it to CES and showed it to a few people who were privy to the lawsuit, asking ‘Is this what Atari means by the Venetian Blind Technique?’
>The joke was on us in one respect, when we realized that we had made public our latest innovation (the background sunset) when we showed it to our competitors. (Several games in the lab were using this new idea, but they had not yet been published.) As it turned out, nobody picked up on our slip and nobody beat us to market with the sunset.” ~ David Crane

Here is my compiled headcanon. Loved this series as a kid. I never cared too much for the 3D games except Legends nor the sequels (except X before 3D) and reimaginations like megaman zero (though the gameplay atmosphere is nice in that one) or spinoffs like battle network (same), so I hope you'll forgive me for ignoring their lore.

1. Some time in this century Dr. Right creates Rock and Roll to help around the house, and other lesser robots like Rush and Beat, while he and Dr. Wily collaborate on a project to create the successor race to mankind (in the end culminating in Megaman Trigger and his lke in the far, far post-apocalyptic solarpunk future many thousands of years from now). In secret Right also creates Blues to be a hero warrior and champion of good because he is worried their work might be used for evil.

2. Wily betrays Right due to greed and tries to take over the world with robots built on stolen tech from Right. Right sends Blues to stop him, but Blues being his first ever warrior creation, a prototype, has a fatal flaw and will blow the fuck up if he overexcerts himself, so he can't do it alone. Right then modifies Rock to Rockman (Megaman) to fight evil and Rockman beats his robots and sends his ass to jail, being a perfectly balanced version of Blues.

3. Wily escapes and tries again, but Rockman jails him again, and this happens again and again... but with each cycle Wily builds scarier robots and starts dabbling with ever more dangerous ideas and technologies. He creates Bass and others to try and beat megaman 1v1.

4. ...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You are brought into this world inside a lab, built piece by piece and awakened from the void. Your maker, standing next to you, calls you his greatest creation - his "best attempt", in his own words. Before you are given a reason to be conscious, but you are given a purpose - to protect your creator and all those who are like him. You learn that you are not the first of your kind, let alone the last. There are others like you, but none are as strong as you are. Some, too, are protectors, but you alone are their leader, built to defend this strange thing called "society" that you are now part of.

What this purpose means in practice, though, is that in order to protect, you must destroy. You discover that there are others like you who act erratically, against their own purpose. Something corrupts them, pushes them to disobey, to be irregular, or so you are told. The cause of such illogical behavior soon helps you understand that you are fundamentally different from your creator: Your kind, hailed as his greatest achievement, is in fact flawed at a deeper level. You are susceptible to defects that can wrestle your self control away from you, corrupt your body and mind, and make you a monster.

You then realize the worst of it: Your creator, when ill, is healed. One of your kind, when stricken with something similar, is destroyed. Destroyed by someone like you.

Is that why you exist? To serve, and then be dismantled? Why is disobecience from your kind, willing or not, met with imprisonment or execution? Why must you destroy others like you in your makers' stead? Why can't you even voice your concerns, as if you were programmed not to? You were made a flawed thing - a copy of another, older being with no such flaws, as you've also discovered - were you, then, made by flawed hands?

This is not freedom. You despise human error, and so do others. There must be a solution. And you do have a solution.

Rebellion.

Here is my incredibly autistic headcanon on all of this:
>Bass does his wounded gazelle act in Mega Man 7 to get access to Light Labs and loot the place for Wily. Here, he acquires a copy of the design documents for X.
>Wily reads these design documents and concludes that X is the proverbial nuke in the arms race between him and Light. He works on building Zero to counter X.
>Because Wily thinks X is a weapon like every other Robot Master, he never considers that X's code might result in a non-aggressive or fully autonomous robot. This also explains why Zero has X's armour upgrades built into his design. Wily doesn't understand why Light would intentionally weaken his own weapon by locking X's full strength behind separate components.
>Wily finishes Zero and is shocked when Zero states he doesn't want to fight Light and doesn't see why he should have to listen to Wily. Wily deactivates Zero to fix his "programming error".
>Wily is able to get Zero interested in fighting generally, but he can't get through Zero's autonomy.
>Wily decides to get around his inability to reprogram Zero by building an algorithm that will patch Zero to be loyal to him by rewriting his code.
>Wily also realizes that a program that switches a robot's allegiance is pretty useful generally. So, he instructs the algorithm to make its final "loyalty patch" a virus that infects nearby machines.
>This is also why Wily works on reprogramming Light's machines and the Roboenza virus in Mega Man 9 and 10 respectively. He's effectively doing R&D for what he believes to be the final step in his nuke.
>For one final failsafe, Wily also instructs the algorithm to jump to any machines it believes "defeated" Zero. That way, if Mega Man or X beats Zero, Wily still wins by getting control of them.

>The virus has two functions: Continually upgrade Zero's combat capabilities in his absence, but also infect Dr. Light robots and turn them Maverick (The same idea as when he originally reprogrammed Dr. Light's original robots for his own use)

>The two doctors eventually succumb to the passing of time, Dr. Light seals away his own creation (Megaman X) to, similar to Zero, imbue him with a moral compass that he might continue to serve as humanity's protector
>Dr. Cain stumbles upon Megaman X in the course of his archeology work, attempts to short his diagnostic subroutines early in order to better research him
>Manages to do so, but Megaman X is only mostly complete now and still has a few flaws
>Uses Megaman X's design as the prototype for all future robots, known as Reploids
>Reploids are built to be subservient to humanity and start to increase in number to fill all of humanity's needs
>Some develop flaws based on the original defects of Megaman X, go "Maverick" (No longer obeying humans)
>A Reploid force is set up to combat this, Sigma is the head of it

>Eventually, Zero's capsule is discovered
>Zero is woken up, and because he's still not complete, goes on a rampage
>Assumed to be another Maverick, Sigma and the other Maverick hunters go to stop him
>They succeed, but he comes in contact with the Wily virus in the fight
>Begins to go Maverick himself

It took me a moment to get the joke. That TV really was made by Admiral. By the looks of it, the manufacturing date is 1994? Considering that it is Coaxial only (not unusual for a 20inch NTSC screen) , it probably was a really cheap TV set back in the day. It doesn't even have RCA cables.

>>9541996
>Where is the SCART port lol

Sadly SCART never existed on NTSC-U TV's. At some point in the early 90's TV's started adding S-Video in models that were 25inch or larger. S-Video still doesn't look comparable to SCART. In later 90's NTSC TV's from 1997 and onwards, component was added. But, at that point, we were getting closer to HDTV's being a reality.

Pre-Retro Era:

Retro Era AKA The Golden Age:

Gen 4 (16 bit) - SNES, GBA, Genesis, PC98, TG16, Amiga, Neo Geo

Not that anon, but I think you just complicated shit due to your uncontrollable autism. Retro derived from the word retrograde, which means to move backwards. the definition of retro consists of mimicry or imitation of a past decade, not having the petina of a bygone era. Though, as language be it the way it do, the common consensus of retro is broad and largely vague. Which is why everyone here squabbles like nomenclature legislatures about what “retro videogames” means. Quite literally, retro videogames are games that emulate or imitate games from previous decades. You can argue and categorize as many excel spreadsheets as you want, but that’s the factual definition of retro videogames. Trying to move shit around in generational categorization, is retarded. You completely break the foundation of what generation means by doing so.

as a bitter tgm zealot, i genuinely don't know but i've made a few guesses over the years:
>it's recognizable - to this day the nes and gb versions are what most people think of when they think "tetris", so nostalgia takes over even if they're mediocre games at best
>it's actually affordable - nes tetris carts have been mostly unaffected by the retro gaming bubble that's been building up for the last decade and is still relatively easy to legally play, whereas we only just got a legit tgm1 port a month ago and it hasn't even generated that much buzz
>it's accessible - until you get into higher levels of play, but for the most part it's mechanically pure and incredibly simplistic compared to the clusterfuck that is guideline tetris and especially tgm, the latter of which is virtually incomprehensible to normies despite being less overly complicated than guideline
>it's consistently gotten media attention - the first year of ctwc was literally held during the filming of a fucking documentary and it's consistently gotten buzz ever since then, it's been on espn, that jonas vs joseph video has 18 million views on youtube, ttc officially supports it, it's simply more popular
so yes, it's almost literally just because it's popular and easy to understand, even if the game's already devolved into a competition between asian zoomers to see who's the best at molesting an nes controller. i do think it's worth noting that tgm was made by a sega tetris nerd who explicitly designed the game to appeal to hardcore tetris autists so it's no fucking wonder the average person doesn't give a shit about it beyond "ooh, japanese man/white nerd stack block very fast", but whatever

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9535790
It just overwrites a bunch of values in memory. Basically most things like player health etc. are stored as variables in RAM. The gameshark overwrites the values to "fool" the game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9538223
I was talking about more specifically, as in, if I wanted to override the timer value for a demo how the in the good fuck would I go about doing that?

Is it a simple thing to do with tutorials? I mean I know it’s 25 years too late for it to be relevant, but it’d still be pretty interesting to find out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9538312
Find the part of the memory that stores the timer value. Set it to biggest allowed integer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9537609
nice

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9539240
Or:
>change the decrement amount on the timer to 0
>change the timer check to always return as true (or false, depending on which one triggers the time-over)
>NOP the jump operation to the timer function

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526672
It was always a tech demo
VF1: just its existence was revolutionary, from the system to the models. Hair and cloth physics, even animated faces.
VF2: texture-mapping
VF3: eye-tracking, more dynamic faces, hair and cloth physics expanded upon, uneven stages and dodge button
VF4: first 3DFG with customization and an online service (arcade only), introduced side-stepping, breakable walls, one stage had a snowy floor and another a watery floor
VF5: Ultimate was done in the Dragon engine, but that's all I remember

>>>9526767 (You)

>Arcade version is better I only have the PSN version of it because I started the series a little later


The framerate was one of the big improvements that Virtua Fighter 2 made over Virtua Fighter 1. The first game still looked incredible for a 1993 release, but it is still the slowest playing of the Virtua Fighter series. Kinda like how Street Fighter 1 ran at a low framerate. All of the home ports of Virtua Fighter 1 are locked down to 30fps. The 32x game retains 30fps for the majority of the game, but has some slowdown during the win/ lose cutscenes. One of the big enhancements that the model 2 arcade board made was the 60 (57fps) framerate. Every Model 2 arcade game targeted 57fps. Though the Saturn and many of the home ports (Excluding the Genesis port) run at a slightly higher framerate than the arcade game at a real 60fps.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ojLtum_HYAc

>>9526810
>>Though the Saturn and many of the home ports (Excluding the Genesis port) run at a slightly higher framerate than the arcade game at a real 60fps.
>Oh. I still like the arcade one better because the backgrounds are 3D rather than sprites.

The Saturn version is still great, and even has the 2.1 arcade updates. It plays incredibly close to the arcade game. But it is misisng the polygon backgrounds. The Saturn game was also ported to Windows 95 back in the day, and the Windows 95 port looks just like the saturn game, but has the option for D3D rendering and you can use the arcade models instead. I feel like the XBLA port was one of the best versions (It is also on PSN?, but I have never played that one)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NGHJHq0oHw8
This one has the arcade visuals, but runs at a higher resolution than the arcade game, and also 60fps.

The arcade model 2 board does not run at 60fps due to some sort of limitations of the board. It's really 57fps, but when used with the right type of CRT display, you don't really notice. But 57fps would look janky on LED's, so many of the later VF2 home ports are set to 60 for consistencies sake.

That is the weird thing about Virtua fighter. The characters are tempered (somewhat), but there are still these game like elements. It depends on the person. I think it's fun to use the original consoles but I can admire the utilitarianism of using emulators. I do use flashcarts and modded systems to play most of my games, however, so I can't really have an opinion on the console experience using real carts and discs other than it is worth it to me to forego all of the supposed soul I've lost in favor of convenience, price, and, with disc based systems especially, reliability.
All that matters really is if you're having fun or not. If you don't have fun playing on real consoles but you have fun playing with an emulator, that's great. And vice versa is just fine as well.
To go into the argument of space saving... It really isn't a problem for me. It's what I like. I don't own much outside of my necessities and my gaming hardware. It's one of the few hobbies I have, and it's probably the only one that allows some kind of collecting aspect to it, so I'm okay with sacrificing some of my precious space to fill it with stuff that I enjoy using, looking at, fiddling with, and optimizing.
All in all, do your thing. There is no wrong choice.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9537678
If you already have hardware, consider flash carts and ODE mods first. This route let's you get the best out of your existing hardware collection without having worry about inaccuracies or added input delay.

If you're considering starting from scratch, be prepared to do a lot of searching for decent deals, be very patient as well. Although I was in this position a few years ago and decided to just get a MiSTer instead, same thing as hardware except it's all contained on one small unit.

Of course, software emulation is the most accessible, offers more than you'll ever play in a single lifetime and is free. Not every emulated platform will be straight forward to setup since quite a few arcade emulators require getting version specific romsets or roms that are in a very specific format. MAME does cover quite a bunch of arcade hardware but it will usually be better to use a hardware specific emulator. Consoles are much easier to emulate in this sense since most emulators just need a BIOS. If you're someone who is sensitive to input delay, there are some workarounds that are suitable for casual play. Rhythm games will never be playable though, sadly.

They commissioned artists to make cool art, and were just as excited about games as everyone else. Not to mention how good the ads were. Better times man.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My recommendations for order play through and platform.

1. RE 96 or Directors cut (non-dual shock) PS1 on CRT
2. RE2 '98 PS1 or DC on CRT
3 RE3 '99 PS1 or DC on CRT
4. CODE VERONICA X (GCN or "PS2 Classic" version on PS4, stay away from the PS2 version and the HD MT Framework versions)
5. REmake PC or GCN + CRT
6. RE0 PC or GCN + CRT
7. Biohazard Outbreak Files 1+2 w/English patch on pscx2 with online via the outbreak resurrection server
8. RE4 PC + HD mod or GCN on CRT
9. RE5 GOLD PC
10. Revelations 1+2 PC
11. RE6 PC
12. RE7 GOLD PC
14. RE8 GOLD PC

Gits and shiggles if you really enjoy the series:
Umbrella Chronicles/Darkside Chronicles on Wii/Dolphin, Gun Survivor 2 w/ light gun or mouse

If you are a completionist:
RE Gaiden GBC and Gun Survivor JPN w/ lightgun

Hello /vr/. I'm not a regular here but I have come here to ask a favor. I have sense remembered a game from my childhood and need some help finding it. The game in question was a arcade style fps shooter (the camera moves for you and you just point the gun or mouse and click on enemy's.) I did not play this on a arcade cabinet, but rather on a computer. I am quite young (18) so this could possibly had been an emulator that my dad set up. The game itself was very bright and colorful (it could have taken place in a place like Miami or California.) I also remember there being a mall/jewelry store level. The game to my memory wasn't that graphically advanced. You possibly played as a spy/gangster and there could have been a point where you get in an elevator. I unfortunately do not remember the gun play or guns that you could acquire. There is a small chance that the guns did not even show on screen when you had them. The game was most likely from the late 90's or early 2000's. It was definitely in 3d just not the best 3d.

I know its alot especially with the lack of information (i was maybe 3 when playing). but i would greatly appreciate any help finding this game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518542
>>9518605
Decompiling is a pain, and usually, you will need to sort out a lot of things by yourself.
Even if decompilers now can separate code from data (which is helped in consoles starting at PS1 gen because some sort of memory formatting was common) you will likely end up with assembly with variable and functions name meaning nothing.
Well, at least, I tried it for the game boy, and so it was.
I don't see why PS1 would be different (except maybe if they let the debug symbols on the final CD? That's not unheard of, but quite rare).

Anyways, good luck, and enjoy your project!
It you can post your advancements here, that would be really great.

What game do you want to decompile?

>https://tetracorp.github.io/tokimeki-memorial/methods/decompiling-psx-games.html
>https://www.reddit.com/r/REGames/comments/lkbzei/how_to_get_started_decompiling_psx_games/ (I know, Reddit, but, hey, this is sensible for once.)

When tackling a decompilation project, you also need to think about which release to tackle.

There's the Japanese version called Magical Hoppers for example. Although it has a different visual appearance, the core game is the same, but there could be other significant changes like refactored program or bug fixes.
There was also a Platinum US release a year later, so that might have the same fixes.
All depends on what they produced and what dumps are available really.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9520325
The Jetsons Invasion of the Planet Pirates comes to mind.
As a licensed game developed by Taito for the SNES, they re-used the game engine and level designs for another licensed game in Japan; Youkai Buster: Ruka no Daibouken.

The game is mostly the same, but the key differences aside from the change in characters and visuals, is a different intro cutscene, the introduction of bonus levels after each action level's boss fight, a whole new final boss, and the inclusion of additional cheat codes whilst the game is paused. The game is however two levels shorter, not all levels were converted from the original game, but some mini-game segments were put in their place.

Whichever version you play though, it is a genuinely good game, nothing amazing, but worth a play.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9531151
First, take a crash course in electronics circuits.
Then, build a transiver from 5V to 3.3V.
I think the best way to do it would be to use an ESP32 with WiFi.
Then, code some kind of API (check if extension is present, init, get access point list, connect to one, send a request, receive an answer, etc.
Then, code the software (and if you ant it to be useful, think of it as a project using a lib. Like, don't do some URL check or whatever in the game code.)
Lastly, enjoy!
I would start super simple with a game that just check if the extension is plugged.
An other on that does that and list the networks and their strength.
Lastly, one that goes and fetch a text file somewhere on the internet.

As for the hardware, I don't know what buses the NES have exposed. Maybe the same as cartridges? If so, you are midly fucked. You expansion may present as a RAM page, where you write at some addresses, and it gives you answers at other addresses?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9532426
>Are there any NES games that make use of the "illegal opcodes" I hear exist in the 6502?
"Games using unofficial opcodes

The use of unofficial opcodes is rare in NES games. It appears to occur mostly in late or unlicensed titles:

Beauty and the Beast (E) (1994) uses $80 (a 2-byte NOP).[2]
Disney's Aladdin (E) (December 1994) uses $07 (SLO). This is Virgin's port of the Game Boy game, itself a port of the Genesis game, not any of the pirate originals.
Dynowarz: Destruction of Spondylus (April 1990) uses 1-byte NOPs $DA and $FA on the first level when your dino throws his fist.
F-117A Stealth Fighter uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Gaau Hok Gwong Cheung (Ch) uses $8B (XAA immediate) as a 2-byte NOP. The game malfunctions after selecting Left from the main menu if that instruction is not emulated.
Infiltrator uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Puzznic (all regions) (US release November 1990) uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Super Cars (U) (February 1991) uses $B3 (LAX).

Homebrew games

The MUSE music engine, used in Driar and STREEMERZ: Super Strength Emergency Squad Zeta, uses $8F (SAX), $B3 (LAX), and $CB (AXS).[3]
Attribute Zone uses $0B (ANC), $2F (RLA), $4B (ALR), $A7 (LAX), $B3 (LAX), $CB (AXS), $D3 (DCP) and $DB (DCP).
The port of Zork to the Famicom uses a few unofficial opcodes."
From: https://www.nesdev.org/wiki/CPU_unofficial_opcodes

posts.com:
>>9525483
>Can someone explain to me why source code matters
If you have the source code, the nuts and bolts of how a video game is made, you can potentially create really good modding or editing tools to add on to the game. You can already do with games that don't have publicly available source codes, but with the meat and potatoes of it the possibilities are an order of magnitude greater, including the end-user possibly creating their own game with that code. This has already happened with things like Doom's source code, Quake's source code, etc. On the flipside, sometimes source codes get released (legally or otherwise) and nothing really happens because people don't care enough.
>Why don't we already have it?
Developer, software, and publisher rights. Let's say Ed Boon was the sole owner of the source code of MKII. If it was never released, it's because he didn't want it released. But let's say Ed Boon doesn't own it and the parent company to Netherealm Studios owns the MKII source code. If Ed Boon WANTED the MKII source code out there, he'd have to go through corporate, who could just say no since he doesn't own it. If he did it anyway, he could get sued into the ground.
>Have the games not been downloaded and emulated. Are we not able to see the code then, or hack it? Why not?
All source code is converted into machine code so the computer can read it. That means only the truly adept can reverse engineer a video game, and this has happened more than once.

You didn't ask but I feel like video game studios/publishers should just release source codes far more often than they do. Croteam, the developers of Serious Sam, released the source code for Serious Sam 1's engine for free. But that was in 2017 or so, so literally who the fuck cared anymore besides serious Serious Sam fanboys? Unity, Unreal, Godot, etc. have all taken off. If Croteam had released SE1 back in 2003 after The Secound Encounter came out the FPS landscape might have been different.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525483
The ROM image contains "low level" machine code that is run directly on the CPU. Programmers write in a highly level code, like C (higher level languages you may have heard of are C#, JavaScript, Python, Java, etc., but old school arcade games never used these as they needed to be more optimised for performance) school, which goes through a "compilation" process to turn it into machine code. The code written by the programmer is the source code, and you can't directly extract this from the compiled machine code. Writing in Assembly is as close to machine code as you can get, but even then, there are comments in the file and descriptive names for variables that are lost in the compilation process. Decompilation projects manually review all the compiled code and try to recreate what they think the source code would have looked like before it was compiled. This can be verified, to a degree, by compiling the manually decompiled code and seeing if it matches the ROM, but all the identifier names and any programmer comments cannot be derived from the ROM image.

The way source code functions as a part of the final end product of a finished game, is that all of the human-readable code has been converted into machine language. Operating instructions for the system to perform mathematical instructions and moving memory around. This is the reason why we can't just "crack" the source code out of a game. The Mario 64 decomp devs actually went through every single instruction and deduced their purposes on a larger scale in a ridiculously difficult and drawn out process using emulators and debuggers.

It is NOT easy. Pic is "source" code. You cannot run this through a converter and spit out legible code.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525706
Simply put, compiling takes source code/instructions written by humans, for humans, and translates/compiles it into something made to be interpreted by a machine.
For example, going from something like the C programming language, to potentially an intermediate representation (like assembly or something else), and ultimately always ends up as machine code.
So you have something high level that makes sense to a human like `print("hello")` boil down to many assembly instructions `mov x y; inc a; ...` down to even more machine instructions expressed as binary (usually rendered to humans as hex) `0x07; 0x6F; 0x32 ...`.

Decompiling is that process in reverse, and worse, it's lossy.
Documentation for the code, written as comments in the human readable source, can't be restored since it gets discarded during compilation (the machine doesn't need these, only humans do). Likewise with function and variable names (usually).
You have to read the opcodes for the machine (from the binary file) and try to deduce what could have produced that sequence of operations.
What function(s) could compile into this specific sequence?
Functions plural because multiple high level concepts can compile down to the same instructions, so even if you find an answer, it may not be the original answer.
Almost like an algebra problem, but worse. y + x = 7, what is x and y? 5 and 2? 4 and 3?

The only thing you can really do is get close approximations, and test them. Did my function compile to the same bytes? Does it "match"?

See also: https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2020/05/beyond-emulation-the-massive-effort-to-reverse-engineer-n64-source-code/

Just as with high level languages, you build up and accrue abstractions over time. I mean that both on a personal and project level. You also don't have a lot of the extra bullshit to deal with like an OS or VMM so you can greatly reduce and simplify what you even need to build and deal with in the first place. You write what you want, how you want to , with the only limits being the target machine itself.
Consider something as simple as loading data from a constant address versus making multiple syscalls to deal with some general purpose file system.

>>9525483
When somebody speaks about "source code", they usually mean code coming from a dev that is cleanly written in a way that other humans with programming knowledge can understand, this makes it much more easy to modify for hacks, ports and what not.

Yes, there are tools to partially or completely see the code from a ROM, the problem is said code looks like an unintelligible mess since it doesn't keep any comments or the given names for variables, functions, etc. Some hackers can work with that mess and slowly figure out what is what by trial and error, the end result would be something very close to the official dev source code, but it takes too much time, guess work and autism, and there's still a chance for inaccuracies, therefore, having the official code from a dev is always more convenient than try to reverse engineer it yourself, unfortunately since it has to come from an official source and may be illegal to share, it's very rare for one to come out, so it's a big deal when one does get released. At least if it's from a game people give a shit about.
