>>9536882
>SMB had worse jumping than Mega Man and fucking elevator physics
As someone who's programmed a Mega Man engine (studied the physics and replicated it all), I love the games but can't agree with this. Mega Man's physics are very basic. You might prefer them because you like having more control after jumping, but there's zero momentum and I think they're much less interesting for platforming.

It works well for Mega Man which emphasizes shooting as much as jumping, but it would be boring for a more pure platformer like Mario.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In their context, when originally released, SMB3 was a better game. It was late in the NES life and was the crowning achievement of the console. It had horizontal and vertical scrolling (don't take that for granted), a huge number of levels and tilesets, a bunch of powers and upgrades, a diverse world, etc. In comparison, the base game of SMW is inferior.

However, currently, SMW is a better game due to rom hacks and kaizos. SMW does have far better movement than SMB3 and is a much better foundational "base" for hacks and mods.

SMB3 should've had tighter movement and fewer autoscrollers (way too damn many). SMW should've had better levels, but that's fixed with modern kaizos.

Look, I loved Mega Man when I owned an NES growing up. I had MM2-6 and played the shit out of them.

Unfortunately, I totally agree that the movement is barebones and basic. Mega Man turns on a dime and there's no acceleration or momentum. His horizontal movement is instant with no ramp-up. I think he even rises and falls vertically at a constant rate.

Mega Man is a game for kids. It's a great series, but it is for children. Maybe some stages in MM1 were tough, okay, but that's it. Any adult who plays platformers regularly should be able to beat MM2-6 easily in a blind run with no game overs.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9538989
not that anon but it's pretty obvious. 3 has tons of levels but they're all 5 seconds long, so that the map feature will work as intended. NES games were famously strapped for content due to all the restrictions of the era, having a game where you could willingly skip tons of the levels in various ways meant that each one needed to be bite-sized so it wouldn't impact things too much on either end. but that wound up creating a negative experience in the end since by the time you get into the groove of playing the level will already be over, just as that anon said.

world was properly able to flesh out the idea of a map and tons of optional levels due to the console it was on, but unfortunately was rushed as mentioned above. both have many compromises for their respective systems.

They're both great games, SMB3 in spite of the hardware and SMW in part because of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Playing Soul Reaver 1 and 2 back to back is so weird. Soul Reaver 1 was nothing short of impressive on the PSX despite the fairly boring gameplay. The textures, the lighting, the effects, the music, the mechanics, switching between the physical and spectral realm in real time in an open world without a single loading screen in sight was no doubt a work of technical geniuses, and it's no wonder the game is so short - it's all packed in one disc.
But then you play Soul Reaver 2 on PS2 and... well, it's the exact same gameplay with better graphics. The animation is impressive sure, but other than that it's barebones. It should've done so much more for being a PS2 game, double the amout of technical prowess Soul Reaver 1 had at the very least. Granted they only had about 2 years to make it but still, it should've done what AAA adventure games are doing today.
But all in all, the gameplay in the Kain series is not its strong point, and can be summed up as "you walking to the next cutscene", but the writing carries it really fucking hard and it rewards patience with a really cool story.

It's not a difficult skill to teach yourself in adulthood. The tools and materials don't have to be expensive either.
Just don't be like countertop faggot and buy a desoldering gun before a fucking multimeter. What a dumb cunt.
- Soldering iron
- Solder
- Flux
- Some kind of fan for blowing or sucking up fumes
- Some low-gauge wire for bodging
- Multimeter
- Side cutters
That's basically all you need for basic troubleshooting and repair. If you get really into it you can go for an oscilloscope, a desoldering tool, and whatever other expensive items.

From what I understand, you really want to get some flux so that you can break the oxidation surface in most metallic components and the solder sticks to it properly. I think that is more important.
And as far as removing solder goes, I'm going to use a desoldering pump, but you may also you those desoldering copper braids.

>>9523926
Took forever. Lots of fucking around with one of those dogshit solder suckers and wick. But there were still a few pins that connect to a large ground plain that I just couldnt get free.

I ended up getting it out with a fucking heat gun. I put the board chip-side down against an iron 45lb plate with the PPU over the center hole. I covered the motherboard with several layers of aluminum foil so that only the PPU pins were exposed. Then I heater it up a bit at a time and started tuggging on the PPU from the bottom underneath the iron plate until eventually I tugged it free

I was so scared that I probably just fried the chip... but it worked. Still going strong to this day

Where the battery connects? Yes, between those two, as well as from one pad of the battery to just about anywhere else. I wiped down the board with alcohol last night, as well as the connectors on the N64 itself, and just tested it again. No difference, game works as usual, but no data stays saved. I don't know if power is completely cut to the cartridge memory when the "Reset" button on the console is used, but using that instead of On/Off still led to memory being erased.
From further reading, the only two things I've discovered are:
1) multiple people in similar situations who said they had broken pin/trace connections to the chips, so they soldered wires directly from whichever pin(s) were disconnected to the appropriate chip. I'd have to spend a lot of time continuity testing and then finding a wire to put on there, which is more work than I'm willing to do, or;
2) I also saw a post from a guy saying that he owns two N64s, and one of them wipes the game data from cartridges he uses with it. If my problem is with the N64, that's possibly another can of worms, and would very likely be the same approach/solution as above. I don't think it utilizes the same CR2032 battery-based save system / PCB model, so I'm not sure if an N64-based fault would necessarily lead to data wiping on it anyway.

>>9519589
>How do you solder these little fuckers?
one leg at a time. the other responses are fucking with you.
put solder+iron on a pad, slide the component into place (this is called 'tacking it down'), remove iron, solder the other side, and then clean up the first side if nits messy.
>Also how do you extract components without fucking up the solder pads
Use heat, not force. If you use force, shit breaks. Stuff will move with basically zero pressure when it's done right.
The exact method depends on the component (SMD vs TFT, simple two-leg devices vs complex multi-leg devices, etc) but for through-hole stuff you just remove all the solder using a good sucker or braid, gently moving the legs as you do so, and components will fall right out.
for small two-contact SMD stuff, you can usually just use lots of solder and a big tip to heat both sides at the same time and slide them off. components may get damaged due to heat when you do this, but the pads will be fine.
>(and if you do how easy is it to repair)?
Not easy. It's not an "experts-only" skill but it's tedious and not for beginners. practice on shit you dont care about because you WILL cause more damage than you fix the first few times you do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541192
If that's the issue then a soldering iron isn't going to help you anyway. Start off by gently cleaning the laser as well as the censors in the open central area of the laser assembly below where the disc sits. If that doesn't help then there's potentioeters to adjust voltage to the laser assembly for reading CDs and DVDs (your problem would be with reading CDs). And if absolutely nothing like this works, then you'd just replace the entire internal disc drive, which is something that you can just unplug and drop a new one in. No soldering required.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541207
Well its a fat Playstation 2 so it might be easier to open. The previous owner did not treat this thing very well. The front door is missing, the far left controller port is missing plastic, and it only opens when pressure is applied to the top of the unit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541215
Honestly I recommend opening up ALL used consoles that you acquire, even if there's nothing visibly wrong with them. Still good to check under the hood and make sure there's no obvious issues with the components or that the inside is caked with dust and roaches or something. For disassembling a fat PS2 just check out an ifixit guide online. Getting to the disc drive and opening that up isn't hard at all. But it's definitely a lot harder to test because you have to reassemble the drive every time you want to see if doing something solved the issue. But drop-in replacement drives should still be fairly easy to obtain. I think they use a fairly generic drive you can swap out.

posts.com:

Also replacing a dry save battery tends to involve the use of soldering, traditionally, so even if there's nothing actually broken on the cartridge, you'd use one for just a piece of maintenance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541219
I do recall hearing about the Playstation 2 being a nightmare to open up, at least on the fat ones. When I was younger I opened my Xbox to see why the drive wouldn't work and found that the belt was decayed and that one of the gears needed replacing. God what a pain.
Thank you for the advice anon. In the event I do need to solder, do you recommend any good kits?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541192
This is what I have https://www.homedepot.com/p/Weller-70-Watt-120-Volt-Digital-Soldering-Station-with-Precision-Iron-WLSKD7012A/320356147 it used to be cheaper. Get something that has adjustable heat settings. Try looking on craigslist or offer up for a cheap used one. You can try turning up the potentiometer on the laser to give it more voltage but that's not guaranteed to work and even if it does it's a bandaid at best. You're better off buying a whole new laser. If I remember correctly they have a few different laser models for the various PS2 fat models so make sure you get one that matches your model. You will have to remove whats called an anti static solder point before you install it. I believe it will be covering some contacts so it won't work if you don't remove it. Make sure you get a desolder braid. Don't worry it's actually very easy to do even for beginners.

>>9541207
>If that's the issue then a soldering iron isn't going to help you anyway.
Wrong. Replacement lasers typically have an anti static solder point that needs to be removed before installation and you need a soldering iron for that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think that out of all super heroes, Spider-Man is the one that's got the better treatment from video games, of course that perception changed over time due to Batman getting his well received Arkham series in the last decade, but before that it was pretty much unanimous that Spider-Man had the best video game career out of all super heroes. I remember playing Spider-Man: Return of the Sinister Six as a kid, it was my first ever experience with a video game based on my favorite super hero, and it was quite good, nothing superb, but it doesn't deserve the poor reception it usually gets, it plays fine enough and has some good level design.

What I really remember from my childhood however, is the PS1 duology of Spider-Man and Spider-Man 2: Enter Electro. I couldn't believe how accurate these were, you really felt like you were Spider-Man, and the jump to 3D helped with that quite a lot. I recall growing up and hoping that there'd be a 3rd installment, but there wasn't, the Sam Raimi films came out and, while I loved those, and both Spider-Man (PS2) and Spider-Man 2 (PSP) played like the PS1 duology, it wasn't set in the same universe... lately I discovered something though, the PS1 original was ported to GBC, which got a sequel... and a 3rd installment, Mysterio's Menace.

When I finally looked at Mysterio's Menace it really took me by surprise, the graphics, UI, power ups... everything seemed like the PS1 duology, and that's because, from what I've read, this is a sequel to that, and not the GBC timeline, regardless if that's the case or not, it sure feels like it. I've just finished a playthrough on Easy and, while nowhere near the experience I got from the PS1 duology, it feels quite good, and it's worthy of the classics I grew up with, the 3rd installment I always wanted. Well then, what are you experiences with Spider-Man video games? I know there are lots of them, good and bad, a lot of memories we can talk about.

I played a part of KH1 as a kid and played through the whole game a couple weeks ago. I had a good enough time, though I found it pretty easy once you got Second Chance. Then I played KH2 which I had never played. I dropped 2. I think a little bit of the jank worked for the first game, prevented you from being too much of a god and gave you reason to use your other abilities. I've seen people insist 2 isn't just mash X to win and your magic is good, but it felt like they streamlined melee attacks but not magic so you either mash X and do a ton of damage or you entirely break your flow to cast a couple spells that do next to nothing. It didn't help that it felt like 2 was dripfeeding you spells, too. I ended up dropping 2 because the combat just wasn't very interesting to me and the amount of cutscenes was just frustrating with how often it took control away from you. And that Roxas intro was so dull.

Overall, I think KH1 was the better game, even though it had its annoyances; I found that I probably didn't finish the game as a retarded child because I kept thinking "where the fuck do I go" and it'd be things like climbable vines that didn't stand out well enough against a tree and things like that.

Yeah, when they’re done well.

Inserting cartoon characters into an already well-established and popular aesthetic (in this case basketball/hip hop) works because it doesn’t break the layer of irony that comes with it. In the case of those Looney Tunes, it’s “cool” because it’s kind of funny.

Whereas with this shit >>9525010, it’s Mickey Mouse trying WAY too hard to look cute in an edgy, almost emo sort of way. The aesthetic itself is NOT well-established so we as the viewer have no idea what he’s trying to pull off with that pose and that outfit. It actually, literally begs the question
>what the fuck did he mean by this?

We can’t feasibly see this as funny, because it’s evident that Mickey is 100% serious about looking like he belongs in a fucking boyband. There is no layer of irony to it, and that is what makes it awkward and uncool.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
KH1 has got the most perfect pacing when it comes to gameplay progression and powercreep

Sora starts with very simple movement and his attacks are very simple, by the end once you face off the extra bosses you really feel like you have grown as a character specially if you craft all end game weapons for all 3, many games fail at recreating this feel and it's very rewarding

Also I do agree with posts above, end game Sora in KH1 feels very balanced compared to end game Sora in KH2

Having said that though I think I like KH2 for completely different reasons, it being a pseudo Devil May Cry with JRPG elements being one of them, also KH2 is more "anime" than KH1 because of all the 1v1 fights and all the cool shit Nomura included in many of the bosses and general gameplay

Really wished the gameplay would have remained good because Square had something great going on before they killed the franchise with BBS (I also like this entry though but modern KH is nothing like what KH1 and KH2 used to be)

Goddamn did it feel good to finally get that PS2 after whatever length of time it was (it felt like an eternity as a kid), spent reading the manual to .hack Infection and Kingdom Hearts, and set that bitch up and play some games.

>>9524382
I was 10 when this came out. This shit was mindblowing to a kid. I grew up with Disney cartoons and FF7 was one of the first games I had on PS1. The commercial with simple and clean would play all the time. Yeah this shit was dope, what a time to be alive.
Thankfully I wasn’t super autistic, but the wave of autism this caused at some kids in school was immense (I am thinking about one annoying retard in particular).
Sequel was good too but wasn’t nearly as magical, mostly liked it for Tron world.

My favorite thing about this game was how it starts you off on this ethereal comfy island with all your friends (who are kid versions of characters from final fantasy games you already played) and then it transports you to fucking Disney animated universe with movies you already watched. It was so weird and interesting, and I really like how they did the 2D Disney cartoons in 3D without losing much in translation.
Embarrassing to admit to liking something so autistic but holy shit this was a drug to a child in 2002.
It lives and dies by its incredible opening, that tropical island as your door to a new universe was expertly done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Many. More people today appreciate Roguelike games than back when Rogue first came out, including retro ones like ADoM. I remember when SimCity 4 first came out, many people complained it was overly difficult to maintain a city and not as enjoyable as 2000 or 3000, now people consider it to be the best in the series. E.T. on the 2600 was considered absolute garbage at the time, now people have read the manual and understand how to play the game it's not considered so bad. Friday the 13th on NES also got left in the weeds, now people consider it a somewhat flawed action game. Starcraft Brood War has more balanced maps, more freedom in map creation, and far more UMS custom maps to play on than it ever has, along with less bugs than it did in the retro days.
Add in mods and hacks, and tens of thousands of retro games can be made better than they ever were. Saving in games that used to use passwords, mods that remove slowdown, mods that fix graphical and text issues, mods that fix bugs and glitches, and so on. Retro videogames are getting better by the day to the point even crappy games like Super Pitfall are getting overhauled into something halfway decent.

>>9530062
Jap was used as a slur in the US in older times, based in the US fighting against Imperial Japan in WW2, fueled by the people who where actually there and fought in the Pacific, those who actually saw the atrocities and crimes of Imperial Japan, as well as those we knew the people who did, those who lost someone in that fighting, and the overall propaganda from the time.

There was also Japanese export goods in the 1950s and 1960s, which to a very large degree was low quality ripoff crap of little value (mind, much of Japan was bombed to pieces in the war, and there was still rebuilding and recovering), combine that with old war animosity and people paint their pictures. Come the 1970s and 1980s, Japan would increasingly start exporting instruments and consumer electronics of actually decent and good quality, so together with better received exports and younger generations who didn't have the closer perception of the war, some of this fades. Of course, there was also a perception of Japanese industry as a serious competitive threat to American industry in the 1980s, so there was some paranoia around that, but then said industry faces some economical hardships in the 1990s.

Overall, "Jap" as a slur for the Japanese is indeed a thing in the US, but it's a faded thing from older times which you don't see in younger generations. Millennials have this idea of it from their older relatives (such as an older relative using phrasing like "Getting Jap'd.", compare to getting "Getting Gyp'd.", but American zoomers have very little conception about its use as a slur, most won't think twice and just hear and use it as a shorthand for Japanese, unaware of any offensive connotations. Of course, if the word stops being used with offensive intent, it stops being offensive.

Honestly, so much of our memory is tinged by personal biases and experiences. I remember WW coming out when I was in Grade 9 and everyone who played it had liked it. I feel a lot of the negative backlash came from a very specific group of people who enjoyed the darker, more realistic direction that Zelda was taking with Ocarina and Majora. As time went on those people either stopped caring about video games or committed suicide because their lives were reaching a dead end. Their numbers dwindled, and a lot of younger people began to discover WW for the first time, without being corrupted by the "muh cartoon" line of criticism. And they discovered that WW is actually a cracking good game with an art style that ages gracefully and still looks pleasing today.

Honestly, WW won in the end. Look at Breath of the Wild. That shit is basically Wind Waker cel shading layered on top of Skyward Sword proportions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SHVC units are the SNES equivalent of the first Famicoms from '83 that got recalled. Avoid that shit garbage; the chips in those self-destruct. The single PPU models (RGB, 1-Chip, and SNES Jr) have some technical changes as well as a different and sharper video signal with the GPM-02 being the only stable, reliable version of the original twin chip PPU.

Yes unfortunately with the early SNESes they rushed out an incomplete beta model and relied on customers to do their field testing for them.

>>9533202
It's some primitive form of Dolby Surround that uses math to encode additional audio channels in the two sterel outputs. If you have a compatible surround system, it'll do some math and basically decode the stereo in to some additional channels. I think it's just some phase shifting and shit like that, no modulation or anything complicated.

Question is why you would need it. I do remember figuring out that A Link to the Past had some nice stereo panning when I first used headphones while playing it, but I don't see much use for additional sound channels in 2D games.

>>9540618
It might have just been that Ricoh had trouble getting the process down at first. The post-recall Rev B chips were still sinked but by Rev D (there was no Rev C) the heat sinks disappeared. I had seen a translated Japanese site where a guy mentions having a really early Famicom from the initial production run and that not only did the PPU get quite hot but it had a really dirty video signal with a lot of interference (this was later fixed by putting a metal shield around the cartridge slot). Apparently (and this was as far as I could discern from Google Translate) it didn't have the full 8 sprites per line either on this initial revision PPU and there was a lot of sprite dropout.

They also had membrane A and B buttons on the early Famicoms that would fall off and were hard to press so those got replaced by hard plastic ones on Rev D onward.

>>9540847
PC compatibles had no sinks up to 386s with the 486 being the first generation to need one and this eventually grew from just a sink to an entire huge fan stack and modern PC cases have vent holes in them as well. There was a thread on VCFED about the necessity of heat sinks in early PCs and it was said that the 8086/88 had no need of them, probably not a 286 either--also there existed CMOS versions of those chips which don't get above room temperature. x87 chips did get hot and needed sinks; they used cerdip packages for thermal reasons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
https://web.archive.org/web/20161106221828/http://jpx72.detailne.sk/collection_files/consoles_files/con_gallery_famicom5.htm

This link shows a Rev A Famicom with the heat sink underneath the PPU. Guy acquired this one, couldn't get it to work, and sold it to a dude in Slovakia, whose archived site is shown here. It displayed a green screen which means the PPU was working but an apparently unresponsive CPU.

It should be stressed that these initial Famicom PCBs from 1983 are rare as they were recalled and the vast majority of them swapped for Rev B boards. If you find a square button Famicom it's usually always a Rev B board.

There are several good ports. My personal favorite way to play is the M2 3D one on the 3ds. They did a phenomenal job and even fish in a given school are at different depths. I have played it emulated many times though with no issue.

I do recommend a guide if you feel stuck, there are two quests near the beginning where you rescue lost dolphins and those give you very useful abilities for the rest of the game.

Finally though, if you find yourself very stuck or the game is too hard, or you just want to play it more casually, all versions including the GBA port have the debug code which is quite robust.

You can yourself invulnerable if you want, level select or teleport to any area of the current zone. Almost more fun though is you can change the music tempo which given Ecco's incredible soundtrack makes for some really cool variations you can do.

Good luck with it, I'm glad to help! It's one of my favorite games of all time, but I understand well why it's always been a little niche. My suggestion if you try again is just take it slow for a while and learn how the game flows. The second level has an octopus that is there to help teach you. You'll feel low on air and like you should be rushing, but the octopus will slap you back of you do. In Ecco, rushing is what usually kills you. Your air is always depleting and you will think you're going to drown if you don't, but success relies on keeping calm under pressure and being accurate. Many people say it's crazy hard, but really outside of the Asterite fight and the Vortex queen at the end, it's really not that difficult ot just takes a kind of mentality that most games don't require as much.

lets not forget that most of the "sister games" back then were just Barbie crap. back then a Dolphin on the cover did not automatically give people the feeling of it being a kids game, hell the Genesis was even marketed as a console for dudebros way before the xbox360 coined that phrase.

you saw Toejam & Earl and you didn't think "oh kiddy alien game" no you thought "wow, thats a whacky bro experience!"

>>9535820
>It's not something like Space Harrier or Streets of Rage that you can play and even if it kicks your ass, still have fun with the pacing

See I guess I just don't see it that way. While I love Space Harrier to a huge degree, I also like Ecco. They are very different, but I don't see that as a bad thing. I hate this comparison being thrown around, but in many ways Ecco is like Demon's Souls was compared to other contemporary games.

From an objective standpoint there are many harder retro games, Ninja Gaiden, Castlevania 3, Super Ghouls n Ghosts, Battletoads, 1ccing Gradius etc (all of which get regular threads here by people declaring that the difficulty is overstated) are all much harder than anything Ecco throws at you, even the last levels. Most games, especially platformers have similar enough controls that you tangentially get good at others while playing it. With Ecco, nothing else plays like it so you're also learning a whole new control scheme.

However, all those games have a similar flow which is much more action focused. Ecco is all about being careful, scoping out the environment with your sonar and clearing an area of enemies so when you have to rush through you can. It's very different from many other console games of the era, but I don't see that as a bad thing.

>>9536263
It's really not a handwave, it's how the game is designed. You can call it tedious, but it was never meant to be a bing bing wahoo rush to the finish type game. Unreliable just makes no sense, if you want to permakill an enemy, you can. It's about making the decision you want to.

Again as I always say in these threads, since first playing Ecco has always been in my top selection of games and I almost always have a playthrough on the go somewhere. Along with that love is the understanding it doesn't appeal to everyone, but I don't see that as a bad thing. Games should appeal to many different people.

>>9526440
Some time in the mid to late 2010s or whenever the fuck, a lot of character designs and whatnot of Mario characters started standardized, most notably Toads and certain enemies. While it's unclear if it is part of the mandate or just Nintendo being lazy/formulamatic, Mario games also followed a general theme structure that was rarely broken (grasslands first, desert second, beach third, etc).
The "Mario mandate" aspect mostly comes from the RPGs, primarily Paper Mario Sticker Star, where the team were told to not to make any new characters (Kersti being the lone exception). Some comments made around the time of Origami King's release suggest that this clause is still in affect in some way, with new characters needing to be very distinct. This standardization also carried on throughout other RPGs where the more distinct and out there Toad designs have been dropped, although NPC variety tends to be a slightly better due to using mooks/Yoshis as well as Toads.
Basically, all of this cemented Miyamoto as a control-freak mad man hellbent on removing the "soul" from the series. Whether or not he actually is in reality is up for debate.

I remember in the early days of Odyssey, some fans were making up rumors that it only released the way it was because the staff somehow managed to hide the game's existence from Miyamoto. I fucking love SMRPG Mario as a character and really wish we got more games with this take of the character.
As someone who never got into 3D platformers, this was the last Mario game I played to completion, and is still the mental image I have for Mario when I play the original NES/SNES games.
Silent protagonist, no voice clips, a "fish out of water" simple guy (but not in the "novice-incompetent" way of the new movie, someone with a fame and looked up to). Communicates through jumps and gestures. Not completly childish, still having some cheekyness (in SMRPG he has moments where he's angry, taunts throwing punches, acts jealous... attitudes I wouldn't picture modern Mario having)
Besides, look at him. Chunky, cute, funny, but rough enough to not give you the "not sure if innocent or retarded" vibe of the modern one. Looks like someone who can be strong. It's like a toy. Makes me want to play with him/as him.

https://iwataasks.nintendo.com/interviews/3ds/papermario/0/2/
>That's right. At first, we were making a lot of individual allies as in a regular RPG, but when we decided to focus on stickers, in order to make a clear change with previous games in the series, it was like we started all over again by throwing out the system—including those characters—that we had made up to that point.
>Yes. We decided to make it so that players would face stronger opponents by throwing out the whole concept of experience points and levels in favor of gradually gathering stronger stickers.
>I had actually been thinking for a long time that I wanted to get rid of the RPG experience points. In the Freshly-Picked Tingle's Rosy Rupeeland28 game, which Kudo-san and I worked on together, the player-character didn't develop at all. We adopted a system whereby they solved everything with money.
>This time, we decided to do everything with stickers. We decided on a system whereby in battle, instead of attack commands, you fight by using the stickers you have gathered in the field or bought in town.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
An overenthusiastic employee made a bunch of ridiculously difficult mazes for the game. They used them in the game just because they didn't want to hurt his feelings. Recognizing that the mazes are, in fact, ridiculous, they included a full guide with the game.
You can go through and draw maps of all the dungeons. This is how I like to do it. It's a kind of challenge that doesn't exist in RPGs anymore. For patient people, it's fun.
Or you can skip all that trouble and use the maps that were included with the game. It's still fun, although there is a bit of grinding. I kind of like the grinding.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9527182
I've been doing this somewhat regularly for about a decade now. I had a few attempts at a single "game notes" book, but that has never materialized. One had loads of notes in it, but I left that with a previous relationship. One of my fondest memories was making maps of the crazy MOTHER / EarthBound Zero factories. The music in these games really burns into your brain permanently, and shapes how you feel. It is super cool to go back and reference old notes, though, on repeated playthroughs. The first time took forever, but this time it's your own previous hard work which allows you to coast more easily through.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: PS2 is my favourite game of all time but you have to enjoy grinding to enjoy it. I fucking love grinding a JRPG party, and I love the difficulty curve of PS2. You are kept perpetually poor, forcing you to work hard to upgrade your party. The ability to configure your party membership throughout the game creates emergent gameplay, like patrolling a small area of the map with a party of 2 to fast level specific party members with specific powers. The difficulty curve makes the minimal story elements all the more satisfying when they're delivered. And the music, aesthetics and atmosphere are just perfect. Its telling that when Sega rebooted Phantasy Star for the Dreamcast, it was the look and feel of PS2 that they sought to translate into 3d

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9535101
Not sure about bugs, I'm OP and I'm playing the improvement patch. It fixes most of the retarded stuff, like super slow walk speed, screen flashing red several times on every hit, game text being all caps, and so on. The game's script is also updated, some items are renamed to be more consistent with the later games. The game mechanics are all preserved intact, there are just light overhauls to tech learning order here and there, as well as removal of the most obviously useless weapons/items. I guess it's the best option if you want the most vanilla version of the game without the bugs / text errors / irritating stuff. there's an option to turn on double exp / meseta if you want, you'll need to apply a separate patch that comes in the archive.
My only gripe with the patch is that the walk speed is a tiny bit fast for towns, doing precise movement may be a bit hard, but it's way worth saved time.

>>9526658
>it's a fucking labyrinth
Yeah, they are. The way I understand it, you are supposed to beat them in several tries: go in, explore, teleport away, heal, go back.
Or use the guide. The mazes are not that complicated though, except for >>9529090
A couple of gameplay hints:
Grinding become easier halfway through the game when you get a set of armor in the second dam that casts Gra with no TP charge.
Robots and magical enemies tend to resist melee damage. Guns and techs ignore resistance.
All guides tell that Kain's techs work on robots and Hugh's techs work on biomonsters. What they don't tell you is that they both work on magical enemies in the later dungeons.

here's a small sample:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9539613
I used to think so too, even after playing through it once getting all four endings by abusing the save system. The battle system needed work (put all points into healing, none of the other techniques matter because melee combat too strunk), the localization drops massive amounts of story detail that was in the Japanese version, monster design and animations leave a lot to be desired after the phenomenal work in the last two games, and a lot of the towns and dungeons feel very copy-and-paste. Why is there a sunny, grass-filled village in the middle of a terminally snowy dome?

Basically, the game feels very unfinished and lacking polish. That being said, the music is on par with some catchy tunes (not many though) and the Generations system gives the game a little bit of added replay value even if by the red generation everything basically wraps up in the exact same way despite the 2nd generation going to great lengths to pit you on either side of the Orakian-Layan war depending on your choice of bride at the end of the 1st.

There's actually a fun little jrpg to have here if you can get passed some of its quirks. It's a lot more forgiving and less-grindy than PS2, at least.

>>9533828
The switch started in Sonic Adventure 1 (Sonic and co start calling him Eggman) and Sonic Adventure 2 (Robotnik starts calling himself Eggman)
By SA1, Sega started going with a unified canon rather than having Japan and the west use different canons. Thus, the Robotnik name was canonized via Maria and Gerald Robotnik in SA2, but the doctor himself was consistently named Dr. Eggman (with the in-universe justification of it either being a nickname he claimed from Sonic or an alias).

>>9535273
Also, another reason this comparison fails is because Vader is a straightforward intimidating villain.
Dr. Robotnik, outside of SatAM and some western marketing, always has a silly undercurrent. He models mechas and a space station after himself. One game has Sonic defeat him by running very fast on a treadmill. He once blew up his own ship. An animation had him ruin Sonic's reputation in response to Sonic being named Man of the Year. The first game ends with him either juggling the emeralds Sonic missed or throwing a tantrum. Even Sonic Adventure, which played him more seriously on the surface, reveals that his personal battleship has amenities like a swimming pool and a toy room.
Eggman can be threatening, as the Sonic CD futures show, and I do feel that later games go too far with making him goofy, but his menace is usually juxtopositioned with his silliness. The comparison fails because Vader is a dead serious villain outside of media that parodies Star Wars.

>>9535403
It depends. The games just vaguely kinda suggested that Eggman wanted to rule the world. Sonic CD and the Sonic Technical Files suggest that it's because Eggman felt that machines were beautiful and could be controlled, with nature being a resource at best. CD goes further to imply that Eggman could even potentially be negligent to his own machines, as his badniks are rundown in the bad future.
>The evil doctor (also known as Eggman) has been a bad egg from the very beginning. Nobody knows quite where he came from, but he is definitely behind any problem that comes up. Dr. Robotnik loves machines. He loves them so much that his idea of a perfect world would be to have it full of nothing but machines. He thinks they are beautiful and he likes that he can control them. A genuine genius megalomaniac, he spends all of his time trying to replace the natural world with his beautiful machines. He is not very concerned about saving the planet (being a notorious polluter), and he particularly likes the idea of exploiting the oceans for their riches (This really gets to Sonic, because Sonic loves the oceans and can't stand the idea of Robotnik messing with them). In order to have ultimate control in his quest, Robotnik must find and control all of the Chaos Emeralds, and most importantly.....Sonic.
Around Sonic LabyrinthSonic Adventure, they gave a more solid goal of establishing an empire with the capital of Eggmanland/Robotnikland and the "mechanizing nature" aspect took more of a backseat.

>>9538086
So many Mario localization changes are utterly nonsensical ("Lakitu" doesn't mean a fucking thing), with Koopa --> Bowser being the worst of them. Before Super Mario Bros., the name Bowser was exclusively contextualized as a generic name for a pet dog in America. The whole arrangement is like if Hitler were renamed Fido, the SS were called Hitler Footlers, and good/neutral German characters in RPG spinoffs were called things like Hitla, Hits, and Hitomi. In games with more atypical localizations, like Super Mario RPG, they already blurred the lines between regions; a simple green Koopa shell is called a Noknok (Nokonoko) Shell, as it is in the original Japanese. I'm sure you're all familiar with SMB3 retaining Kuribo's Shoe and Jugem's Cloud. The changes were ultimately unnecessary and simply a product of their time.

"Goomba" is also worth mentioning as a particularly stupid localization. The original term applies more to Mario and Luigi than it does to the mushroom enemies. If Super Mario Bros. debuted today, there's no way they'd have changed the names like this. The older I get, the more it bothers me.

>>9541217
N64tismo here, it's better than ever now
PJ64 is still the easiest and most toaster-friendly way to emulate the console and there's ways to disable the annoying support-nagging message.
There's a lot of Mupen64plus builds with user-friendly GUIs if you don't want to deal with PJ64, Mupen RMG and Simple64 are the best options imo.
Retroarch has the parallel64 core which tries to be as accurate as possible, you need a good PC to run it so have that in mind, the Mupen64 cores also work fine enough but you need to setup the core settings properly first, I did that and I can play N64 games alright on my phone.
For Graphics plugins, GLideN64 is the best for speed/low-specs and other things like custom texture-loading, Angrylion plus and Parallel are the most accurate ones but you need a good computer/phone to run them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541217
It's quite decent now, but there's still some caveats. Project64 is a bit of a clown show now. The last stable build is alright, but the latest nightlies are full of regressions, with games that used to just work without fiddling breaking left and right, and I would stay away from them for the moment. It also doesn't come with the best available plugins (particularly the ParaLLEl plugins), so you gotta get those from elsewhere for the best experience.

On the Mupen side of things, it's sort of split between RMG, Mupen64Plus-Next and simple64. The first one is a straightforward fork that just bundles an actually usable GUI and the best plugins, so it's quite good. The second is RetroArch's version, which from my experience has the best audio and input latency and can use nifty shaders, but has a couple of performance regressions here and there. The last one is a hard fork that's more accurate than the others and fixes issues present in every other emulator and only uses a single set of VERY accurate plugins for extra simplicity, but it's also the slowest.

Then there's ares. It's currently the least compatible of all the emulators, but it could potentially become the best one, as it's essentially taking a bsnes approach. Overall, I wouldn't much recommend it over simple64 just yet, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541297
Some of it has to do with the N64's unusual architecture, but a lot of it has to do with its history. It was heavily fractured between a bunch of competing emulators, and a lot of design decisions were made early on across all the emulators (mostly for performance and short-term-gain reasons) that hit a brick wall around 2010 or so and froze progress for a good while. The worst of it was heavy reliance on HLE graphics emulation, which is inherently hacky and heavily contributed to the plugin hell situation the scene is known for, and the other is lack of proper cycle counting, instead relying on hacky workarounds like CounterFactor. Sure, this allowed you to play Mario 64 on a Pentium III, but it caused countless issues for a myriad other games, and the scene was very slow to transition away from the HLE-hacks-and-workarounds approach. Only now are they finally embracing LLE and accurate cycle counting as worthwhile goals to fix the remaining problems.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541346
The N64 is a lot more complex than the hardware before it. I'd wager writing a whole new emulator from scratch isn't easy. Also, not all of its ins-and-outs are documented yet (of course, there's the infamous Oman archive leak that most likely was consulted by early emulator devs, but that's neither here nor there). I think at the end of the day, though, there just wasn't much interest. Most of the popular games are plenty playable even on toasters, and that's what they ultimately cared about. Without a byuu-like autist to push the envelope, complacency tends to kick in.

There was, of course, CEN64, but unfortunately its developer had somewhat unrealistic expectations about being able to get it to run at good speeds on current rigs, and when he was unable to achieve it, he sort of lost interest and left it to the n64dev community, and now it's more of a documenting/debugging tool than anything.

Speaking of byuu, ares is the most current attempt at a highly accurate emulator written from the ground up for accuracy without (mostly) relying on older code, and it's made pretty good progress, all things considered, even if its RDP renderers aren't original. Still has a good way to go, though.

>>9541395
GC and Wii have a more traditional hardware architecture, so emulating them using OpenGL or DirectX are simpler. The N64, however, has an alien an primitive architecture, it was derived from a SGI workstation so it predates OpenGL and common 3d conventions. Emulating that is hell.

I love my CRT, but even I admit that we're getting VERY close to the full obsolescence of CRTs. OLED motion clarity at 240hz is nearly identical, and input lag has come down to 4ms — that's far more appealing than the 1-16ms of variable input lag you'll get on a CRT. Video scalers with genuine hardware represents our last step towards the final goal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536439
The game barely has a story honestly. The later ones have stories that are intentionally goofy, but get a lot of screen-time and give characters clear goals, motivations, etc.

In DMC1 the story is that Trish shows up, tells Dante the demon emperor is being resurrected on some random island, leads him there and then just fucks off to leave him to wander around aimlessly killing demons. There isn't really a clear objective or any indication of how this is supposed to stop the villain. It's like that for most of the game until it suddenly remembers it has a plot at least like 2/3rds of the way through.

In spite of that it does sort of have a theme or at least a parallel between the plot and the backstory, with Sparda being a demon, a creature of evil, that had a change of heart and became good, just as Trish is a creature created for evil purposes that ended up becoming a good guy after being shown compassion by Dante. So it's one step up from being just an excuse for the gameplay... maybe.

I wasn't trying to blow anyone out, I just thought it was an interesting mystery to solve. At first I thought about skimming Next Generation magazine but I decided to search for the name online instead. I found another post by the same guy from around 2003 saying he got pics from RPGFan. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: What are your favorite driving levels in retro games? (Driving levels in games that otherwise have you on foot, of course.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541651
The Portchartrain Bridge level in this game is so good, it's pretty straight forward, but it lets you go real freaking fast while spewing flames on the side like something out of evel knievel. The night time levels in New Orleans? were fun, sneaking your car inside the truck was such a bond move.
iirc they had the team need for speed team working on these levels. Explains the race mission.
Gosh, this game had so much going for it, idk why people prefer Nightfire over this, it has so many bond elements, and even has Brosnan's voice and John Cleese to top it off. It's also better farewell to Brosnan. Though it would've been nice to flesh out Willem Dafoe's character a little more.

Honestly, Nigthfire peaked on the first level on the snow mansion, (not the first training level, that's a glorified qte on rails interactive cutscene) The quality starts to drop drastically afterwards. Like they placed all their eggs on that basket right away and nothing else in the game lives up to it,, missions just get simpler and straight forward after that MGS/NOLF like level at the start. I heard The multiplayer is quite good, but not as good as Agent Under Fire. I never played either MP, though. The vehicle section also felt like an afterthought, 1 button does all vehicle gadgets whenever the game lets you, the awful underwater level, and that atrocious flying mission that goes on forever.

Agent Under Fire campaign's at least stays fun through out the whole thing, short and sweet levels that don't over stay their welcome, and all are some kind of homage to a bond film. I love that it embraces the wackier side of Bond franchise, too. This version of bond is also very classic, like a mix between Moore, Lazenby and little bit of Connery rolled into 1
Everything or Nothing goes full on blockbuster but in a good way, lots of variety. I need to replay From Russia With Love, I don't remember liking it much back then, didn't find it as fun as EoN.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9524408
Unfortunately, it's not easily obtainable knowledge, you should know C, you should understand how the compilator processes your code and you should understand the assembly language of a target platform(MIPS in the case of PSX). Tools allow you to decompile an executable file to asm functions with generic names, even convert them to c. But it's not like load exe to Ghidra and getting a working code.

In rare cases, devs forgot the symbol file on a disk so you can obtain names for functions and variables but usually, they don't. So you need to guess names for thousands of functions and variables.

Reverse engineering is a hobby for a high skilled and autistic programmers.

Ease of use is also a main factor, but it's true that most here don't make anything. There are disassemblies like Sonic for Gensesis where you just download everything and double click a batch file to make it. Then there's numerous other games, like the source releases already mentioned, that expect you to go in blind with installing "something" and have no clue what the starting point is supposed to be to compile it. You're either going to be spending 30+ minutes to just install Cygwin and 30+ minutes to get it to 'make' the file once or maybe there's something else that's specially necessary for whatever OS the source was meant for. I know certain sources require setting up DOSbox just for it to compile, but where is a site that even explains how to build everything without digging through a retarded Discord server?
I've come across multiple Discords for obscure games with some aspect of a modding community like the guy that made the hack called Joy Mech Fight Special. The GBAvania speedrunner named JupiterClimb somehow has a more active hacking scene IN his stupid Discord in comparison to any other site or Discord that's meant for that purpose. If you want to know how to compile and use the Star Fox source leak, join the Star Fox EX dev's Discord, because the info is practically nowhere else. You have to dig for tutorials and questions in the most retarded places, anymore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9538226
Yup. For me it's playing SMB1 the first time, and finally getting to play it for a long time during a sleepover with a friend who had an NES. Glorious. I think we only made it to world 5 without warping.

Also getting SMW Christmas 1991. It was amazing. The game was so colorful, the music was amazing, the controller was comfortable, the world map expanding was full of exploration and opportunity. That night I made it to Donut Plains 1 and got the cape, and the sunset sky background stuck with me.

Then there was Doom in 1993. Finally getting to play it on a fast computer, with a nice 17" monitor and a sound card.

Then there was SM64. Playing it the first time at the Kiosks they had setup at Toys R Us the summer of 1996 before it came out. Me and my bro rode our bikes 4 miles everyday to go play it. 3D finally felt real, and like real life. Mario and the controller instantly melded into my hands, and the connection to my brain was unlike anything else when it came to control. Felt like virtual reality with the familiarity of my old friend Mario, but a new adventure.

I'm rambling now, but those are definitely the amazing moments of gaming for me. The PS2 and MGS2 and GT3 are up there. SSBM, Metroid Prime... WoW... Hell even COD4 MW on PS3. Nothing really since.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541616
The original is Lotus Esprit Turbo Challenge on the Amiga. Lotus Turbo Challenge II is almost as good, but not a racing game. (Don't bother with the megadrive version).

The whole aesthetic and gameplay of the SNES Top Gear games is based on those, but to my mind takes a biiig step toward the casual. The original Amiga game is the greatest scaling racer ever made, though you may have to get your teeth into it to appreciate why. It's like discovering a completely new class of motorsport.

A few years ago I was watching random Game Center episodes, my parents and my brother were out of town so I went to my brother's bedroom intent on smoking some of his weed (I had smoked before). He had some sort of dust in a grinder thing (I have no clue about weed stuff other than just smoking it very occasionally).
I put some weed in the pipe with the dust and smoked, waited half an hour and nothing happened, figured I'd smoked too little and just left it at that, then went to take a shower. I was in the shower for a good half an hour before I realized I was finally high. All the lights hurt, and directly looking at one for a brief moment made my ears feel like I was getting hit with cymbals in the head. All I could do was fall on my bed, cover my face with a pillow and focus on Arino's voice until I felt well enough to get up and turn off the lights. GCCX stood there running with me all night, keeping me safe from my druggie demons.
Thank you Arino-san.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9539823
I have a hunch as to what the problem was. My suspect is that ARAH was one of those games that reads back the PPU registers but that only works on Rev G chipsets (on earlier revisions they're read only). The Rev G was introduced during 1989 so a NES made before that date will have the older Rev E chips. Best way to test for this without opening it up is running Micro Machines as that will glitch on the title screen if you have a Rev E.

MM was an unlicensed game to fair, but ARAH and TTA were licensed yet it's possible that they eluded Nintendo's Q/C checks anyway. A playtester at Nintendo probably just ran the games on a Rev G console and they worked with no problems so it passed. The fact that both games are quite late ones would also mean there was a good chance that the devs were using Rev G NESes to play and test them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Famicoms with the hockey stick logo on the front had the revision G chipset so they're easy to identify. for NESes it's a little harder but IIRC the chipset change coincided with Nintendo switching to fireproofed ABS plastic so if the NES looks yellowed it's probably a Rev G chipset, but only running Micro Machines would confirm it.

posts.sub: PAL or other later region release differences
posts.com:
Hello, do you know any games that have significant differences in their PAL release? Or games that have had changes when released in territories after their original release?

I had always known that in the Gamecube era, Nintendo games that released in PAL would have minor alterations such as bug fixes in Metroid Prime or balance changes in Smash Melee. But I learned recently that in PAL regions, Luigi's Mansion had a hard mode that was actually significantly different than the original! The ghosts are distributed differently, the mansion is mirrored, the mansion is darker, and all of the damage values are turned up! I really missed out playing the US version as I love the game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yorda's speech translated

In the initial playthrough of Ico, Yorda's speech would appear as runic symbols on the bottom of the screen. On a new game started from a cleared game file (referred to as a "second game"), Yorda's speech is translated.
Two-player mode

After starting a second game from a cleared file, a second player can play as Yorda (by adjusting a new "Players" setting in the Options menu).
Shining Sword

A secret weapon that looks (and even sounds, as it swings) like a lightsaber from Star Wars. The blade can vanquish shadows easily, and it has a very long reach if Ico is holding Yorda's hand.
Film-grain effects

A new option that allows the player to select from various film overlays, making the game look similar to an old film. (The overlays are used in various parts of the regular game, including the early cutscene where Ico sees a shadow dripping out of Yorda's cage).
Extra ending

At the end of the game, Ico walks down a long beach to meet Yorda. If this is a second-playthrough file, several watermelons will be behind a large rock near the beginning of the path (the boat "points" right towards it). If Ico picks up one of the watermelons and carries it all the way over to Yorda, an extended ending will play showing them sitting together eating watermelons on the beach.

>https://teamico.fandom.com/wiki/List_of_changes_from_the_U.S._version_of_Ico

In the original PAL release of MGS2, when you started the game it asked you if you've played MGS1. If you said you haven't played MGS1, it skipped the tanker section entirely and started in the Big Shell as Raiden.

This happened to me when I played it back in the day, and looking back on it now I think it's kinda neat that I only had as much information as Raiden did - for example, the game actually managed to convince me that Snake died in some tanker accident years ago and this Navy guy was called Pliskin

As a result, they decided to create a fork called Swanstation, and Stenzek went on to make claims about it using "stolen code from his private repo" for which he never provided any proof, and it all came to a head when he found out about a cloud gaming service known as Piepacker that was using Swanstation for PS1 emulation, which was reported to have made a few million in profits, and that it was employing a libretro contributor at the time. He went absolutely nuclear over all this, and he ended up conflating all these things together and made up a narrative that the libretro team was making millions off of his stolen code, and used it as an excuse to cease working on Duckstation altogether, which then pissed off dicksuckers in Reddit, Twitter and Resetera, who promptly attempted to cancel libretro and RetroArch. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9521549

They're zoomer retards, it's that simple, don't try to reason with them.

They think they are "recreating" the "effect" of a CRT screen, but that's not what they are doing, and unless they have a HDR 8K monitor that's barely even possible. Let alone on the garbage 10 year old 1080P panel they probably use them on.

The annoying thing is, filters are not a meme; but the real function is to simply break the image up. That's what a REAL CRT does. It's a form of natural anti-aliasing, it's an optical illusion that tricks your eye into thinking the pixels blend together. If people were making filters that did this without trying to replicate a CRT we would probably have vastly superior filters.

Personally I just use a 50% opaque scanline filter, and increase brightness to compensate, making sure the line integer matches the internal rendering resolution. When I play from sofa distance I can't see the lines, it just looks like a smooth image instead. It's not as perfect as a real CRT but it's better than the eye-strain inducing garbage of "CRT filters".

>>9526446
Animation, sound, art design, level design/variety are all top-notch. Boss design is great and plenty of enemy variety. Primary and secondary weapons are well-balanced and there is a trade-off between more firepower vs. higher rank.

What I really love though is the slower, more deliberate approach to the game. I think that's what a lot of people struggle with, this is a game where you are really meant to proceed with caution and really take advantage of the fact that the game doesn't autoscroll. Every time you play, you get a bit more efficiency, a bit better method to approach a section, and can better parse the vast amount of information that is thrown at you at once. And then when you start to get really good, you can do speed strats (unfortunately there is no scoring incentive, but still fun). It's definitely a game that grows on you.

>>9530843
The game itself is not really that slow, especially when you know what you're doing. If you mean slowdown, yeah it is pretty bad (just like the Metal Slug games), but you can remove it through emulation and the game is massively improved.

The rank system is kinda fucked though; the game is actually easier if you don't pick up all the powerups. You need to make the decision between rushing past sections or going slow and thorough. When you learn the game, you can do sections very quickly and pointblanking shreds bosses.

Just like with the Slug games, turbo + removing slowdown makes the game so much better. With turbo you can also pointblank the last boss and it dies way faster (he also has less health with lower rank from not picking up as many powerups). I'm not sure what other problems you are having with the last level, it's just all about routing and figuring out how best to approach each section consistently (like any good shmup/run-n-gun)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526418
From a casual perspective, it has great artwork and sprites....but the game isn't that fun. And games THRIVE based on the casual player.

From a casual player's perspective:

You are getting by enemies from above AND below (no room to breathe). Your area of movement is limited to a narrow section of water (assuming the stage isn't in the way). The stage constantly shifts and shoots out random rocks or coral reef to block or kill you. And worst of all the game treats your submarine's main weapon, the TORPEDO, like a normal bullet. It doesn't feel satisfying to hit an enemy with a big torpedo only for them to shrug it off. Then you gotta fire 5 or 10 more torpedos just to kill them. That's not how submarine warfare should be or feel. The whole thing feels stiff.

If I saw this in 1993 at the arcades (I might have), I wouldn't play it more than a handful of times and never try it again. And based on what I saw, In the Hunt wasn't that popular at arcades. Not like later games of the 90s.


Like other anon said, the submarine levels in Metal Slug were much more well done, and approachable. It embraced the wackiness of the level without going overboard. You could hop in and out of a submarine as a diver and still shoot enemies. You could shoot bullets from your submarine (yes I know it's not possible in real subs, but I accept that for fun gameplay). You could move around in a larger area. And lastly your torpedoes actually matter. They have big power behind them. Metal Slug just got everything just right in gameplay and design.

In the Hunt feels like an earlier version of Metal Slug's submarine levels. An early version where things aren't properly fine tuned or correctly balanced. Like an early draft. But it has great artwork and sprites though.

I can see why hardcore schmup fans like In the Hunt, but I don't enjoy it as a casual player. And if I don't enjoy it, then I won't replay it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9539243
You have to use the green and blue missiles to one-shot enemies, the red is more for rapid-fire. There are tons of times where you peek out, pop a depth charge or missile and then slink away, it's pretty great. For damage output though, generally you want to pointblank with your depth charges or balloons.

The main issue is just the rank system. The game is much more fun and more manageable at lower ranks, but casual players are just going to pick up every powerup. I do also think it could benefit from a slightly faster movement speed. I think slower movement speed is great for the type of gameplay it rewards, but it could be just like 10-20% faster.

Metal Slug's submarine stages are just way too basic in comparison. I never found them that fun, and having to move towards enemies to fire at them is just a bit janky.

>>9539457
>slowly erodes from discs and cartridges

Wrong terminology. Data doesn't "erode", it "decays", but even then, it doesn't "decay" on physical. In fact, physical is the format most likely to outlast digital. Kodak film negatives can last up to 1,000 years, CD's can last well over 100 years even in less-than-good conditions, with 50 years being on the low end of the spectrum.

M-Disc's, currently the standard in archival long-term storage, also last 1,000 years, and it's already over a decade old.
